item.title: Cost Effectivenes Analysis and Cost-benefit analysis of mitigation/adaptation options for pasture systems, rice, fruits, rubber and soybean in Colombia
item.description: For mitigation, four subsectors are being analyzed: i) Silvopastoral systems, ii) improved pastures, iii) efficient use of nitrogen fertilizer in rice, and iv) converting degraded pasture to fruits. CIAT is organizing several national workshops to identify regions with major potential to implement silvopstoral systems and improved pasture. In rice, N-Fertilizer dose-response curves are being modeled and inefficient levels of nitrogen fertilizer use identified. Local workshops are being held with producers and local technicians to identify alternatives for improving use-efficiency of N-fertilizer. Regarding fruits, modeling is being used to identify the most suitable locations for growing avocado and mango. Economic information about costs and benefits are being calculated for different locations and a national level MAC Curve is being built. Regarding adaptation, climate change impacts on pasture, rice, soybean and rubber are being estimated and some adaptation measures are being identified by different stakeholders in local workshops. Cost for every measure is being calculated and cost-benefit analyses carried out.

item.title: Assessing the potential of tropical forage options to mitigate climate change through reducing nitrous oxide emissions and enhancing carbon sequestration
item.description: The livestock sector accounts for 40% of the total value of global agricultural output and provides livelihoods for nearly 1 billion people. Improved tropical forages could offer the single most effective means to mitigate climate change from agriculture and land use change, while also sustainably boosting production of milk, meat, and crops. Livestock are estimated to be responsible for about half of agricultureand apos;s total greenhouse gas emissions. But forages, particularly brachiaria grasses, can offset these emissions through diverse mitigation pathways. These include: (i) carbon sequestration in soil through their deep and abundant root systems, and (ii) reduced emissions of nitrous oxide. Brachiaria grasses suppress nitrification in soil through the release of biological nitrification inhibitors from their roots, an ability known as biological nitrification inhibition (BNI). These inhibitors have the potential to improve recovery of applied nitrogen to crops (e.g., maize) and reduce nitrous oxide emisions from agropastoral systems.

item.description: Crop response to management practices in different production systems vary spatially and temporally but blanket technological recommendations tend to be applied and generalized across wider geographies leading to variable responses/results. To define the target domains for management practices that are adapted to climatic variability it is necessary to understand the response to crop management under a range of soil, climatic and production systems. A wide range of data, from different sources, exist on short- and long-terms trials of different management practices in various cropping systems and ecologies. These data, if collated and analysed, could provide important insight into defining suitable recommendation domains.

item.title: Matching of historical maize and amp; wheat germplasm evaluation data with GIS data and current weather data
item.description: Every year CIMMYT sends promising lines coming out of the breeding pipelines of the global wheat and maize programs to a large number of partners in NARS located globally for wheat and in Africa, Asia and Latin America for maize, each location representing mega environments defined for both crops. The mega environments are utilized by the breeders to plan and target their breeding efforts. Many institutions evaluating these lines send feedback on yields, phenotypic information and pest and disease scorings. This data set, spanning several decades, can be utilized to analyze the impact of climate variability on yield in a large variety of environments. It can be used to calibrate crop models like DSSAT or APSIM over a long period for many different locations worldwide. Information on pests and diseases can be utilized to generate risk maps based on related climate data extracted for the individual locations. For all these purposes, the precision of the locations of the nursery sites has to be as high as possible. A large number of the sites were georeferenced when GPS was not available and thus often inaccurate. This emphasizes the need of the first step in correcting the inaccuracies with current tools and GPS information from nursery site managers. Based on this, creating the analogue layers will enable determination of the areas the nursery sites represent under current climate conditions. Utilizing climate change data sets will allow the identification of those areas that are predicted to have the climate conditions today other maize and wheat growing areas will experience in the future and to identify those areas that are under climate conditions currently that the nursery sites will experience in the future. This will allow the breeders to test new breeding material in such environments and to plan for shifts of climate and mega environments.

item.title: Analysis and modeling of wheat trial data to identify climate ready traits/ideotypes, and analogue sites in climate vulnerable regions with the medium-term objective of developing phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators.
item.description: The first main objective of this activity is to identify the key stress adaptive traits, and combinations of traits, that will be needed to maintain productive wheat crops in warmer regions now and in the future climate scenarios. This will be achieved through analysis and modeling of detailed wheat trial data from heat stressed experimental environments. While conceptual models for adaptation to heat stress have already been developed by CIMMYT, simulation exercises using comprehensive data sets can help determine the levels of expression of traits required to maintain productivity across the range of stress profiles that are likely to be experienced in target sites, as identified by climate models. Clearly, for this information to be applied, experimental sites must be established where germplasm can be evaluated and selected for expression of the appropriate phenotype. Therefore, the second main objective is to develop phenotyping platforms with NARS collaborators so that they can breed for probable climates, e.g. 20 years into the future. While climate models can establish the broad meteorological parameters of future environments, the outputs from crop models will determine which aspects of growth will be most affected. This kind of information can help define the key characteristics of analogue sites since any given analogue site is only an approximation of a range of target environments. For example, it may be that reproductive growth becomes a new bottleneck to productivity, and therefore, it will be crucial that the stress profile at the analogue site around the crop stage of meiosis and anthesis closely matches those characteristics of the future climate scenario at the same growth stage. This is not only determined by air temperature but also relative humidity, radiation load, and water availability, since these factors also influence the expression of plant temperature.

item.title: Development of abiotic (heat and combined drought and heat stress) and biotic screening sites in partnership with NARS to evaluate the resilience of key maize germplasm to future climates
item.description: Climate predictions for EA and IGP show temperatures are likely to increase however very little research has been conducted in maize for tolerance to heat stress and combined heat and drought stress. There is currently limited phenotyping capacity for both heat stresss and combined heat and drought stress in EA and IGP. Repeatable screening protocols for drought stress can be achieved by screening in the dry season however screening for heat and combined heat and drought stress is much harder to manage resulting in loss of trials if a suitable stress level was not reached and large genotype x year variability. The establishment of a FATE facility will allow carefully controlled stress to be applied at the field level. Climate change is also likely to change the prevelance, diversity and responsiveness of maize pests and diseases, thus further work is required on screening for biotic stress.

item.title: Quantify impact of climate change on maize and bean system in Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador.
item.description: Central America is highly vulnerable to extreme events and unfavorable future climate conditions. A climate disaster often leads to crop failure and harms farmers resilience and food security. Farmers have already experienced unforeseen climate variability in the past and need to cope with uncertainties every day to sustain agricultural production. Climate change means they will have to face additional long-term shifts of climate patterns as shown by global climate predictions. The project Tortillas on the Roaster seeks to predict site-specific changes in maize-bean production systems in order to inform and enable vulnerable farmers to act and respond to ongoing climate change through specific adaptation measures and increased capacity.

item.title: Develop supply chain adaptation frame work, that outlines ways for supply chain to adapt jointly.
item.description: Global climate change (GCC) presents serious challenges to agricultural systems as they strive to meet growing demand over the coming decades. Within these systems, food value chains are increasingly recognized as vital for development. Yet relatively little is known about the vulnerability of such chains to GCC, or their adaptability. This activity provides a framework to examine how food value chains adapt to the uncertain impacts posed by GCC. While intervention models mostly deal with measures for producers, we hypothesize that adaptation strategies must include the entire chain to achieve the scale needed to tackle GCC. We propose that comprehensive situation assessment is necessary to examine both behavior and assets two key attributes for adaptive capacities. Our framework examines three sets of attributes: 1) The general setup and nature of the supply chain, 2) rural livelihoods and food supply systems vulnerability to GCC, including downscaled crop suitability modeling to assess precise impacts of global climate change and 3) the behavior of people and entities involved in value creation and the institutions mediating them. The framework provides decision-makers with a scale-, crop- and site-independent road map to design and evaluate adaptation strategies to changing climate conditions. We test the framework on three case studies with differing supply chain characteristics and geographical contexts.

item.title: Identifying crop wild relatives (CWR) collecting gaps for 80 genepools for climate change adaptation pre-breeding
item.description: Crop Wild Relatives (CWR) are widely recognized as sources of genetic variability. Thanks to their close relatedness with cultivated species (CWR include crop ancestors) and the ecological niches they are adapted to, there is an increasingly growing interest in using CWR for adapting crops to the environmental conditions that climate change is expected to impose. Despite their importance and potential usefulness, CWR lack adequate representation in germplasm banks (e.g. Less than 5% of germplasm accessions of Cicer, Cajanus, Oryza and Phaseoluscorrespond to wild material). Gap analysis techniques enable us to identify which species need further collection and where in the world they are found.

item.title: Multi-site evaluation of Brachiaria grasses (germplasm accessions and hybrids) and tropical forage legumes (species and germplasm accessions) for drought and waterlogging to respond to increased vulnerability due to climate change
item.description: Tropical forage grasses and legumes grow over a wide range of environmental conditions. As of yet their response to climate change has not been well defined. Optimization of forage systems for future use with respect to yield and nutritional quality can therefore not be performed without new experimental evidence. Seasonal drought and waterlogging are dominant features of tropical agroecosystems, and both quantity and quality of forage production can be markedly affected by these stressors. Tropical grasses and legumes show considerable genotypic differences in drought resistance and forage quality. Multi-site evaluation of brachiaria grasses and legumes with farmer participation contributes to identification of climate-adapted forage options for integration into crop-livestock systems.

item.title: Comparative adaptation differences between tepary bean and common bean characterized
item.description: Tepary bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) is a desert species of the tertiary gene in relation to the common bean. Tepary has traits that make it particularly well adapted to extreme climates of heat and drought that are expected under climate change. It could serve either as a source of traits for the improvement of common bean, or as a useful species in itself. In either case, the acceptability of such as ideotype (small seeded with poor market potential; limited biomass; etc) should be tested with farmers before launching into a broader effort to utilize tepary.

item.title: Analysis of survey data and to identify and document formal and informal risk management strategies employed by the rural poor in the IGP
item.description: Agricultural sector, and in particular farmers, are highly vulnerable to risks due to high variability in climatic conditions and to market uncertainties. Farmer exposure to risk and uncertainty is often aggravated by lack of information about weather, inputs, farm management practices or market prices, and this lack of information has an adverse impact on crop production and income. Some of these risks, for example the risk of a bad monsoon, affect agriculture as a whole, while other risks vary from region to region, and the severity of their impact depends on an individual farmer knowledge and coping ability. The evidence suggests that a farmer who receives quality, up-to-date information, and who has the ability to use that information, is able to lessen the effect of these risks.

item.description: The integration of data from different sources (e.g. International Wheat Improvement Network -IWIS-, crop and climate model output, information from adaptive crop management research; GIS and socio-economic data, etc) can be used to develop technology packages that will complement farmersand apos; risk management strategies for regions most vulnerable to climate change. Information from crop and climate modeling exercises can permit more focused deployment of that germplasm to specific target regions, facilitated by socio-economic information to help with prioritization of the most vulnerable communities. Once identified, the target regions can be analyzed for apparent yield gaps that can be closed with better crop management as well as a range of alternative cropping systems that could ameliorate some of the negative impacts of climate change. This project aims to make a cost benefit analysis of these adaptive technologies, resulting in communicable outputs that can be used by a wide range of decision makers and amp; farmer service providers (seed producers, NGOs, extension). In terms of prioritization, resource-poor farmers, particularly vulnerable groups and women, in at least 6 countries will be targeted. Towards the end of the project, stress adapted cultivars will be disseminated as nurseries and training in crop management practices and/or alternative cropping systems for target regions will be delivered to decision makers and farmer service providers in NARES and other relevant groups in the delivery chain.

item.title: Effects of early and late maturing varieties and early and late sowing, as farmers coping strategies on yield, Rhamphicarpa and Striga assessed
item.description: Parasitic weeds, an important group of weeds in rice in sub-Saharan Africa, are progressively spreading due to their invasive nature and adaptive abilities. This is particularly worrisome considering projected demographic and climate changes. The most important parasitic weeds in rice are Striga hermonthica, S. asiatica and Rhamphicarpa fistulosa. We aim to prepare rice farmers in threatened areas against likely increasing infestations with these weeds by investigating vulnerable locations, effects of climate anomalies on parasitic-weed survival, reproduction and virulence, direct and indirect economic impacts, and sustainable management strategies for resource-poor farmers. Stakeholder interviews, field observations and measurements, yield-loss assessments and farmer-participatory experiments in hotspots (Benin, Cte dIvoire, Madagascar and Tanzania) combined with controlled climate chamber experiments and different modelling approaches will enable us to do meaningful predictions on future invasions and agronomic and economic impacts, and develop feasible management and policy strategies for prevention and containment to support stakeholder decision-making.

item.title: Evaluating rice responses to pathogen strains under various climatic conditions
item.description: To enhance Africas rice production and reduce reliance on imports, rice yields per hectare need to be raised significantly, despite climate change. Major determinants of the current low yield levels per hectare per hectare (average of about 1 t ha-1 in upland ecologies, 1.5 to 2 t ha-1 in rainfed lowland ecologies and 3.0 to 4.0 t ha-1 in the irrigated ecologies) are biotic stresses, in particular two major rice diseases: blast and bacterial leaf blight, whose effect on rice growth and yield is very much affected by weather conditions, in particular temperature, air humidity and soil moisture status. The use of resistant varieties is the most economical and effective way of controlling these rice diseases in resource-poor farmers fields. Unfortunately, because of the highly variable nature of the pathogens, it is difficult to manage blast disease through the use of resistant cultivars because of the breakdown of resistance. WARDA and partners are conducted research to analyze the structure of the pathogen populations in order to ensure safe deployment of resistant varieties. A focus on East Africa is very much needed, because information on rice diseases in that region is very scarce. The expression of plant resistance to blast and bacterial leaf blight is known to depend on climate. In many plant pathogen systems, climatic conditions impact both on the occurrence and gravity of diseases attributable to micro-organisms such as fungi, bacteria, viruses and insects and on plant response to diseases. The impact of climate change on blast and bacterial blight diseases of rice has not been documented. According to the International Panel on Climate Change, East Africa and especially the Great Lakes Region are among the more vulnerable regions in Africa to climate change. The trend is towards increasing temperatures and declining rainfall, all factors that may intensify disease occurrence and severity. Disease occurrence may deter farmers from investing in intensification measures because of risks related to yield losses or even total crop failure. The development of rice varieties that resist these diseases under current and future climates is, therefore, of great importance. This will require the evaluation of current pathogen population structures and the likely impact of climate change on the evolution of host-pathogen relationships. With such knowledge it will be possible to mitigate the impact of climate change on rice disease resistance in East Africa and enhance and protect the livelihoods of smallholder rice farmers.

item.title: Identify promising incentives, institutions and market-based mechanisms and policies for adoption of conservation agriculture by smallholder farmers in EA
item.description: The economies of most countries in Africa are heavily depend on the agriculture sector. The performance of this sector , however, is constrained by several biophysical and socioeconomic factors. Soil fertility depletion is considered a major biophysical factor limiting per capita food production for most smallholder farmers in the region. When no external inputs are used, plots require long fallow periods to replenish nutrients taken up by crops and washed away by erosion. However, as the population increases and the availability of new land to exploit decreases, allowing plots to lie fallow has become more and more difficult, and continuous cropping has become commonplace in Africa. This has resulted in a vicious cycle of poor agricultural productivity, low investment capacity, continued soil degradation, and further pressure on available lands to generate necessary food supplies. Greater adoption and diffusion of conservation agriculture practices (CAPs) offers a means of addressing some of these problems. The potential benefits of CAPs lie not only in conserving but also in potentially enhancing the natural resource base without sacrificing yield levels. Despite their benefits and a number of national and international initiatives to encourage farmers to invest in them, the adoption rate of CAPs is still low in rural areas of developing countries. In order to address this, a greater understanding is required of the farmersand apos; incentives, institutions, market-based mechanisms and policies that influence the adoption of conservation agriculture by smallholder farmers in EA.

item.title: Optimal sowing windows for irrigated and upland rice and associated risks in Senegal River and Niger River, for present and future
item.description: Adaptation will be fundamental in securing the achievement of the UN Millennium Development Goals after 2015 in sub-Saharan Africa. ESCAPE will move beyond the static view of vulnerability assessments and the linear extrapolation of climate scenario impacts to facilitate pro-active adaptation that is scientifically sound and socially acceptable. Once vulnerable sectors and/or people have been targeted, research will be focused on increasing their adaptive capacities by designing new adaptation strategies that would be able to reduce their vulnerability to climate variability and change. This research will consider a user-driven definition and perception of problems and needs, as well as mutual learning by assessing both scientific and local knowledge. A better knowledge of how local actors such as farmers already adapt to climate variability and extreme weather conditions such as droughts and floods is essential to design and propose new adaptation strategies that can be adopted and used. ESCAPE aims to assess the vulnerability of rural societies in sub-Saharan Africa to climate and environmental changes and to explore adaptation pathways to reduce this vulnerability. This will be achieved by fostering inter-disciplinary research, through both retrospective and prospective studies, on the evolution of different agricultural, ecological, and social systems interacting together under the global environmental changes.

item.title: Contribution to framework and databases allowing for integrated decision making with respect to adaptation, mitigation and policy interventions
item.description: Ensuring global food security in the face of climate change. The global community must find a way to provide food and water security for a population expected to reach 9 billion by 2050. Global carrying capacity for food production and our ability to protect carbon-rich and bio-diverse natural ecosystems from conversion to cropland ultimately depend on achieving maximum possible yields on every hectare of currently used arable land. Yet for most major crop producing regions of the world, including data-rich regions such as the U.S. Corn Belt and The Netherlands, there are no reliable data on yield potential (Yp). Water resources to support rainfed and irrigated agriculture also are under pressure, making the efficiency with which water is converted to food, water productivity (WP), another critical benchmark. The target is to find the exploitable yield gap (Yg)the difference between current average farm yields and Yp. Accurate estimates of Yp, Yg, and WP, and their year-to-year variability, are critical to increase yields and make the best use of land and water resources. Unfortunately, previous efforts to estimate Yp lack agronomic relevance. The Global Yield Gap and Water Productivity Atlas (hereafter called the Atlas) will provide a web-based platform for estimating Yp, Yg, and WP that is transparent, accessible, reproducible, geospatially explicit, agronomically robust and applied in a consistent manner throughout the world. The Atlas will enable farmers, governments, policy makers, foundations, the private sector, and others to: (i) identify regions with the greatest potential to increase food supply and water use efficiency; (ii) provide input to economic global models (either computable general equilibrium models or partial equilibrium or agricultural sector models) that assess food security and land use; (iii) prioritize research investments, and (iv) evaluate the impact of climate change and other issues that deal with water, food, and weather. The Atlas is an international project that requires on-the-ground efforts because it is based on local data from each of the worldand apos;s major crop production regions on soil and long-term weather, planting and harvest dates of major crops in existing cropping systems. A standard protocol for assessing Yp, Yg, and WP will be developed by leading scientists around the globe and it will be based on a strong agronomic foundation. This protocol will be applied in a bottom-up process that uses local experts and networks to provide knowledge about crop management and productivity and existing soil and climate databases. These data will be used with the most appropriate crop simulation models and a geographic information system (GIS) to produce detailed maps with associated databases displayed and accessible through an interactive web-based platform suitable for expert and non-expert users. To the extent that IP restrictions allow, all data and models used in the Atlas will be made publicly available.

item.title: Optimizing the value of historic breeding trials to model adaptability of potato and sweet potato clones (proof of concept)
item.description: CCAFS is trying to systematize and make available the information generated in the Centers through AgTrials and to use this data to generate information for the technology produced by the Centers and Partners to help farmers adapt to progressive climate change. Since the early days of the CGIAR their breeders have conducted field trials with partner institutions around the globe, testing the adaptation of genetic materials to different environmental and management conditions. Unfortunately, most breeding trials do not record growth and development traits in the rigorous manner required by modelers to estimate the parameters to model the expected behavior of a crop under different climatic and management conditions. All the breeding trials record biomass at harvest and visual indicators that allow scientists to make germplasm selections and recommendations for different conditions. In this activity, originally planned to be conducted during 2012 and amp; 2013, we will use allometric relations in combination with heuristic knowledge, based on breederand apos;s visual assessments, to infer the growth and development parameters from historical breeding trials. We expect to develop tools based on numerical and artificial intelligence algorithms with minimum data input: location, planting and harvesting dates, harvested product and some qualitative aspects. The program is expected to derive proxy growth and development parameters suitable for modeling the expected behavior of particular genetic materials under different present and future climatic conditions.

item.title: Developing methods to jointly model geo-spatial climate covariates such as topography, soil fertility and pests
item.description: Efficient site-specific agricultural management requires a thorough quantitative knowledge of (i) spatial and temporal variability of crop yield within an agricultural field or a region and ii) factors and interactions influencing crop yields. The main factors influencing crop yields are field topography and soil properties, including soil fertility and moisture. Complexity of crop yield variability often could not be fully characterized by traditional statistical approaches. A multifractal analysis can provide detailed additional information about data spatial variability and has been utilized for analysis of various spatially distributed natural phenomena. An extension of multifractal theory for analyzing more than one variable called joint multifractal theory was developed in the physical theory. Joint multifractal theory can be used for conducting simultaneous analyses of several multifractal measures existing on the geometric support and for studying relationships between the measures. As the topography controls soil water distribution in semiarid environments where water is the major growth-limiting factor, in this study topographic attributes that best represent the spatial variability and scaling properties of crop yield will be identified and used to improve the capacity to model yield across scales under different climates. This approach aims at reducing the uncertainty of forecasted yields under climate change scenarios thus improving the reliability of CCAFS outputs needed for decision making. We will start by showing the importance of spatial variability in assessing productivity. The second step is to test the suitability of the proposed approach to improve geospatial yield forecasting when topography and soil-water processes are incorporated in the model; and third, we will attempt introducing the pest component in the model aiming at improving CCAFS capability of jointly modeling most important processes limiting productivity under climate change conditions.

item.title: Multilocation participatory trials of durum wheat in Ethiopia carried out in analogue sites for present and future adaptation to climate change
item.description: The diversity of genetic traits of crops represents our most important resource for adapting agriculture to 21st century climate change. Ethiopia is a country rich in agricultural biodiversity and it is considered a major centre of crop domestication in Africa. The high diversity within cultivated crops can be used to adapt local farmers systems to climate change. An important means for small-scale farmers to adapt to climate change is by shifting their crop varieties to those better suited to future environmental conditions. Changing varieties is the main adaptation strategy to temperature alterations, and the single most important strategy, after soil conservation, to changes in precipitation patterns. However, roughly half of the farmers surveyed were unable to use different crop varieties, due to the lack of available information. This indicates that improving farmers access to information and seed material from adapted varieties will considerably improve their ability to sustain food production in the face of climate change through the increased use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture.

item.title: Multilocation participatory trials of various crops in 4 countries carried out in analogue sites for present and future adaptation to climate change
item.description: Farmers who depend on agriculture for their lives and livelihoods must be able to adapt to changes in climate in order to avoid falling deeper into poverty. This requires identifying crop varieties that are better adapted to yield under changing climatic conditions. A wide diversity crop genetic resources is being conserved by national and international genebanks and is also present on farm. These collections include varieties that could make the difference for poor farmers in the changed environments of future decades. Identifying varieties that are adapted to drought, floods, heat and pests, along with information about them and their use, can help farmers to avoid famine and poverty brought on by the disastrous effects of changing climates on their crops. Therefore, by working with national partners, including local communities and womens groups, this activity will facilitate the identification of stress-resistant varieties of target crops that are currently being conserved, and match them with the areas where they will continue to produce yields under predicted future climate conditions. The identified varieties will then be distributed to farming communities for multiplication with the help of local agribusinesses. Participatory Varietal Evaluation as an instrument to strengthen local practices that support diversity maintenance through team work. item.title: Development and evaluation of methodologies for surveys of communities in three countries about climate change and the relative tolerances of traditional crops including NUS to cope with climate change conditions (Nepal, India, Bolivia)
item.description: This activity is part of a global effort supported by IFAD aimed at better understanding the role of traditional crops in the adaptation strategies of local communities to climate change. Today there is very little information available on these crops, how they are being cultivated by whom and for which purpose. The underlining hypothesis is that traditional crops are more resilient than commodity crops. For this reason and in view of other livelihood contributions (nutritious food, income options, ecosystem services and immaterial benefits) their conservation and sustainable use need to be further supported. Surveying their use and gaining greater insights on their resilient properties as perceived by user groups is thus fundamental. Critical is also assessing the status of their conservation in view of the increasing erosion threatening both their genetic diversity and associated knowledge. Data are being gathered through household surveys and focus group discussions in pilot sites across Bolivia, India and Nepal. Our aim is to capture information and knowledge from community members (using gender sensitive approaches) and compare these across sites of same/ different countries and region. At the same time, we are also interested to assess the effectiveness of methods deployed in these surveys for a wider application. This work is also closely linked with the development of participatory documentation and monitoring systems for traditional crops which would include also a novel Red Listing approach for cultivated species.

item.description: Musa genetic resources (with emphasized on wild relatives) need to be collected and evaluated before they disappear. They should also be studied in all their different range of habitats. This should allow avoiding gaps in the diversity collected and facilitating selection for specific traits. Banana plants are not easy to evaluate in the field at a large scale, therefore an early rapid method would allow to screen under controled conditions a large number of genotypes in a relatively shorter time for their tolerance to drought. The selected plants will then be tested in the field to validate their tolerance. Breeders and other users are constantly requesting more evaluation data for traits linked to drought but also for other biotic or quality traits. The generated data need to be accessible to the Musa research community through the Musa germplasm Information System (MGIS) to which 22 Musa collections are already contributing data.

item.title: Collating and sharing information on the use of indigenous/local technical knowledge in deploying crop diversity (especially NUS) for strengthening adaptation and resilience of production systems to climate change in 5 countries (PNG, Malaysia, Bolivia, Nepal and India).
item.description: The scope of this Activity is to assess the role that indigenous knowledge plays in enhancing the use of local agrobiodiversity for greater adaptation of local production systems to climate change. The study will be carried out based on data gathered by two projects implemented in South/ East Asia and Latin America and will help answering a number of important questions regarding to role of local crops (NUS in particular) in adaptation and resilience such as 1) Which are the most resilient crops and what is the knowledge held by communities on their use? 2) What are those traditional practices that make use of NUS for enhancing adaptation/resilience? 3) How is knowledge being held and shared within the community and what are the threats and impediments to its conservation and valorization? 4) How does knowledge differ across men and women and how gender-related perceptions/actions complement one another? The analysis will also try to understand 5) How different socio-cultural-economic settings influence the way knowledge relevant to climate change and biodiversity is perceived, appreciated and promoted by people.

item.title: Selection of promising genebank accessions of durum wheat and barley for climate change adaptation in Ethiopia and buckwheat and oats in China on the basis of their passport data, current and future climate profiles.
item.description: Crop diversity have been undergoing a long process of natural and human selection and gaining resistance to various biotic and abiotic stresses imposed by climate change. Crop genetic diversity can be used not only to counter the negative impacts of climate change, but are also the resources to be used for breeding new varieties with resistance to pest and disease, drought, and extreme temperature variation. There are abundant crop genetic resources in China and currently about 0.4 million accessions are conserved in national collections. These accessions possess various characteristics and could be the physical basis of crops adapted to climate change, meeting the breeding requirements and ensuring food security. In particular, various minor crops possess the traits of resistance to pests and diseases, tolerance to drought, poor soil and extreme environments, and have great potential for adapting to climate change. Buckwheat (Fagopyrum spp.) and Oat (Avena spp.) are ancient crops that have long been grown in China and the Himalayan region. Although they are minor crops, buckwheat and oat are indispensable food in the temperate and hilly countries of East Asia, East Europe and the Himalayan region. Moreover, they are major staple food crops in the high-altitude zones in southwest of China. In addition, buckwheat and oat have wide adaptability to unfavorable conditions and tolerance to drought and barren land. They are cultivated easily with short growth period of 70-90 days. Particularly, buckwheat plays an important role in food supply as a re-sown crop in famine year due to other crop failure.

item.description: Diversified households often incorporate a number of strategies including diversifying crop production within a farming system through intercroppings and rotations, incorporating new production systems within a farm such as livestock husbandry and fish ponds, off farm wage labor, migration wages, and often combinations of multiple strategies. Furthermore, management and technological advances may be coupled with diversification strategies as prerequisites or enabling factors of diversification, and outcomes from diversification strategies. This activity considers the differential impacts of such diversification strategies based upon scale, region and production system.

item.title: Formalizing local perceptions of climate risk
item.description: Most ancient Agrarian societies use bio-/ethnoclimatology indicators to inform planting and other farming decisions. In the context of increased climate variability and change, this information is used to develop adaptation strategies. These societies have also developed formal and informal information networks to communicate about the seasons conditions, and making planting decisions. With increasing uncertainties such as the onset of rainfall and rainfall patterns, there is need for long term monitoring of changes in the behavior of bioindicators, their use in decisions about farming, and the relationship between the behavior of indicators and climate forecasts in relation to outcomes of decisions. This activity aims to 1) Gather and systematize existing knowledge on ethnoclimatology in different agrarian societies and climatic conditions; 2) Understand, decode and learn about local communication networks and mental decision making models; 3) attempt to elicit the most important common features in the use of bioindicators and decision making; 4) Assess the feasibility and pertinence of formalizing and reproducing local knowledge with the use of artificial intelligence; 5) Characterize the information needs to incorporate CCAFS forecasting into the local language and networks; 6) Explore and identify ways of building synergies between traditional and numeric forecasts to improve decision making in agriculture; and 7) learn and take advantage of participatory processes used by farmers to develop new knowledge.

item.title: Modelling climate-sensitive pest and diseases for potato- and sweet potato-based systems
item.description: Climate change will precariously affect agricultural production and the livelihood of farmers in Africa by unpredictably changing the abundance of insect pests along with their existing and potential natural enemies. The project seeks - through innovative phenology modeling and risk mapping - to understand the effects of rising air temperatures caused by climate change on the future distribution and severity of major insect pests on important food crops in Africa. This will be achieved through the development of generic analytical tools (software for decision making) that require and foster collaboration through joint model development and application of modeling results for adaptation planning addressing the different stakeholders and target pests. As a result, the scientists of national research institutions in Africa will be trained in applying simulation methodologies to assess the vulnerability of agricultural systems to major pests - due to climate change - and to identify adaptation strategies to cope with future pest problems. The project builds on CIPs experience in insect simulation modeling and risk mapping, as well as, on the provision of Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software. This software will be further improved and adapted to cover a wide range of insect pests, and to meet the needs of the different stakeholders. The results will fill the current knowledge gap about climate change effects on economically important insect herbivores, especially in the tropics. The project is a collaborative effort of three International Agricultural Centers (CIP, IITA, and icipe), the University of Hohenheim, Germany, and their partners at NARI in Africa.

item.title: Develop an Online/ offline mapping tool for rapid risk and impact assessment of CC effects on LB - validation of look up tables
item.description: Late blight has long been known as a weather driven disease and this has certainly been a major factor in the development of weather-based forecasting models that assist farmers in scheduling fungicide applications. Late blight is favored by moderate temperatures during the day (10 to 26 C) and high humidity (over 90%) during the nights. However, these conditions vary greatly in time and space, so that the dependence of the pathogen to weather conditions has been the subject of study to guide fungicide applications according to weather data. Weather has also been used for traditional management of late blight by farmers who knowingly plant potato in dryer seasons thus trading off potential high yield for yield security; and also by farmers who have traditionally planted more susceptible varieties in higher mountain locations where lower temperatures restrict disease progress. Climatic change will undoubtedly change the production potentials and risks for small scale farmers; with potato late blight this could be a major factor because of the sensitivity of the disease to weather factors.

item.title: Develop precise submodels for T and RH on LB development using current SAS based simulation model
item.description: The intensification of potato production and the management of potato late blight generally involves a high number of fungicide applications and is known to have unacceptable side effects on farming communities and the environment. Computerized models for disease simulation have been effective tools in the evaluation of strategies for disease control. They allow preliminary assessment of a number of scenarios involving many variables, including level of host resistance, aggressiveness of the local pathogen population, and specifically weather conditions and different potential climate change scenarios. There are good reasons to believe that potato late blight will become more severe in the developing world with the expected higher temperatures and increasing rains. This study aims to improve the adequacy of the late blight simulation model LATEBLIGHT (version LB2004) by improving temperature and relative humidity models in the simulation model LATEBLIGHT. The activity will measure leaf wetness and leaf temperature in the potato canopy of field plots with the use of recently available nano sensors and correlate results with micro verification of lesion growth and epidemic disease development.

item.title: Tools for stakeholder adaptation planning for Musa and its pests and diseases, cocoa and coconut
item.description: Understanding the interaction between banana, cocoa and coconut interaction and their growing conditions (temperature, water, light, nutrients, relative humidity) has been an important undertaking of research for many decades. The International Musa Germplasm Testing Program (IMTP) was an early collaborative initiative to evaluate new germplasm in many different environments. This data set was initially used to identify highly adapted cultivars that performed well in many climates. A growing concern with climate change coupled with targeting of food security in rural communities has led to a research approach based on climatic differences and their importance for crop performance and the severity of pests and diseases and vulnerability of rural communities to food shortages as a result of climate variability and change. Banana, cocoa and coconut present challenges for climate change adaptation since all three crops are multi-year crops, although they are found in quite contrasting growing conditions. We propose to use models, tools for spatial analysis and regional networks to build stakeholder capacity to plan adaptation strategies for these three crops.

item.title: Development of a regional strategic action plan for PGRFA management for climate change adaptation in Mesoamerica -- climate change impact and climate information needs studies, policy and institutional analysis, participatory discussion and design processes, expert consultations, case studies
item.description: According to climate projections for the coming decades, Mesoamerica is one of the regions in Latin America expected to be most severely affected by climate change. Besides increases in temperatures, rainfall is expected to decrease significantly during the 21st century with longer and more pronounced droughts. Mesoamerica is also one of the worlds diversity hotspots and a centre of crop diversity. Several major globally important crops (e.g. maize, beans) were domesticated in this region, and a great variety of landraces of these are still cultivated in farmers fields. For other important crops, such as cassava, Mesoamerica is a secondary center of diversity. Research increasingly indicates that plant genetic diversity is the single most important resource in adapting crops to rapidly changing agro-ecological conditions and changing pest and disease patterns. Plant genetic resources for food and agriculture (henceforth PGRFA) are crucial for food security and health. However, there is still a lack of understanding about the potential to adapt to these changes precisely through the conservation, use and exchange of PGRFA. In the regional Mesoamerican context we are here addressing, all this has limited the contribution of PGRFA to the food security and sustainable development of the region and has resulted in limited capacity to formulate multisectorial policies which incorporate PGRFA in effective adaptive pathways against climate change. In order to fully take advantage of PGRFAs potential for responding to food security and climate change challenges in the general context of environmental sustainability, the present proposal puts forward the development of a participatory, science-based, regional Strategic Action Plan (hereafter SAP) for the enhanced conservation, research and use of PGRFA in the Mesoamerican region.

item.ccafs:objective: OVERALL OBJECTIVE: To sustain food security and livelihoods under changing climatic conditions based on improved conservation, use of and access to Mesoamerican PGRFA. Given the global relevance of several native crop gene pools (e.g. maize, beans) and the interdependence of countries on these, the project will contribute to the adaptation of agricultural systems to changing climates and therefore to food security in Mesoamerica as well as in other regions of the world.

SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES: To have regional and national entities formulate and endorse a strategic action plan which outlines key research and policy priorities for the coming 10 years. The framework provided by the SAP will guide countries in the identification and coordinated implementation of priority regional and national actions for strengthening conservation, use of and access to Mesoamerican PGRFA.

item.title: Develop a climate downscaling methodology based on wavelets, multifractals and neural networks
item.description: Crop-simulation models provide an important tool for assessing the potential implications of seasonal forecasts on agriculture. However, the coarse spatial resolution of global and regional circulation models used in seasonal predictions makes it generally necessary to downscale these predictions to scales suitable for driving crop models. Precipitation and temperature downscaling improve the coarse resolution and poor local representation of global climate models and help end users to assess the likely hydrological impacts of climate change and should also enhance modelers ability to generate more realistic climatic-change scenarios. In the case of rainfall, end users demand reliable representations of precipitation intensities and temporal and spatial variability, as well as, physical consistency, independent of region and season. In this sense, remaining gaps are uncertainties arising from sparse data; representation of extreme summer precipitation, sub daily precipitation, and full precipitation fields on fine scales; capturing changes in small-scale processes and their feedback on large scales; and errors inherited from the driving global climate model and its propagation towards regional models. Unfortunately, conventional downscaling methods do not seem to account for the spatial variations across scales. The non-linear approaches used in this activity are anchored in statistical physics and are hypothesized to better account for physical and orographic processes influencing spatial climatic variability. We thus expect to deliver products more in line with the demands of the end-users and complementary to other CCAFS downscaling efforts. In close collaboration with Climatic research groups, downscaling products will be used as input to crop models to ascertain the performance of downscaling protocols comparing different climate input and contrasting modeling results with historical yield data and expert knowledge. Models will also be used to assess how global warming will affect the ability to grow food, at different spatial and temporal scales.

item.title: Methodology development and data collection (data needed for drought indices/modeling)
item.description: West Asia and North Africa (WANA) like other dry areas worldwide is characterized by low and extremely variable rainfall, frequent droughts and land degradation which are exacerbated by climate change. Consequently, Agricultural productivity is low and unstable. One strategy that has the potential to provide large productivity gains and sustainability and hence improve the livelihoods of poor people who live in rainfed and marginal areas of WANA region is the development and use of proactive systems of drought preparedness and mitigation. This study aims at identification and synthesis of existing technical, institutional and policy options of adaptation to drought, the development of drought vulnerability maps under progressive climate change conditions using drought indices such as SPI and test and demonstration of improved and more adapted techniques/technologies such as supplemental irrigation, drought tolerant varieties in rainfed areas and water harvesting and adapted shrubs in agro-pastoral zones. The role of water allocation in rainfed areas will be also evaluated using modeling to save water and improve its productivity under drought and progressive climate change conditions The study will be conducted in two main benchmark sites, rainfed (Morocco and Syria) and marginal (Jordan) areas.

item.title: The use of the Focused Identification of Germplasm Strategy (FIGS) to select best bets for adaptation to climate change
item.description: Prospects to assess and explore untapped plant genetic resources/biodiversity for crop plant traits to adapt to climate change are possible through new approaches such as the focused identification of germplasm strategy (FIGS). The FIGS approach is based on the paradigm that any germplasm such as a germplasm with adaptive traits to climate change is likely to reflect the selection pressures of the environment from which it was originally sampled. FIGS approach uses both trait and environmental (climate) data to develop a priori information or specialized knowledge based on the quantification of the trait-environment relationship using different models/algorithms. The a priori inforamtion is then used to define a subset of accessions with a high probability of containing the sought after traitss such climate change related traits. The approcah has helped in recent years to find long sought after traits such as resistance to diseases and pests.

item.title: Community-based identification and evaluation of rangeland and forage species for tolerance to drought, cold and salinity, as potential sources of climate change adapted germplasm
item.description: Rangelands are found all over the world, encompassing almost half of the earths land surface. In non-tropical dry areas, rangelands are the single largest land use type, covering over two-thirds of the total land area. They are the main source of feed, fuel-wood, and medicinal herbs for millions of resource-poor pastoral and agro-pastoral communities whose livelihoods depend on rangeland-based livestock production. Moreover, not only do rangelands support livestock production, these lands also provide society with valuable products and services that support our standard of living and quality of life. These products include ecosystem services such as mitigating climate change via carbon sequestration, purifying water via bioremediation, and storing genetic diversity within the flora and fauna of these environments. More recently, however, many rangeland areas in the region are not properly managed resulting in feed deficits, soil erosion, loss of plant biodiversity, and expanding desert margins. Unfortunately, when it comes to rangeland rehabilitation and management, most development projects have focused on exotic species which requires substantial amount of water to get established such as Atriplex and Acacia. The proposed activity will focus on identification and assessment of indigenous and well adapted fodder species that have evolved under local harsh conditions. These species which in most cases are becoming rare (endangered) will be promoted.

item.title: Monitoring of population changes and adaptation of insect pests and diseases of cereals and legumes
item.description: Global change is affecting pests of many crops in the world. The expected decrease in precipitations and increase in temperatures as a result of climate variability and change as well as changes in cropping systems would have great impact on distribution and economic importance of insect pests and diseases affecting cereals(wheat and barley) and food legumes (faba bean, chickpea and lentil). Varying levels of precipitations and temperature extremes would favor latitudinal and altitude extension of the geographical distribution of the insect pests and diseases as well as parasitic weeds of food legumes. These climate changes could also create favorable environmental conditions for some secondary insects and diseases to become key pests. Recently the use of simulation modeling like CROPSYST and ecological niche modeling like CLIMEX and GIS are used to map distribution of pests in relation to biophysical factors. Surveys need to be continuously conducted to assess the importance of insect pests and diseases and monitor changes in their populations structure as might be influenced by these climate changes.

item.description: Most climate change scenarios predict reduction in rainfall amount in the dry areas (less vegetation cover and more erosion) but more frequent high intensity and erosive rainfall events. The impact of different management strategies to adapt with this change will be modeled and the application of soil conservation and water harvesting interventions will be promoted. Most of the existing robust models were developed under humid conditions and therefore these need to be fine-tuned to suit arid conditions, which are highly vulnerable to climate change.

item.title: Adapting to extreme events in Southeast Asia through sustainable land management systems (2012-14)
item.description:
The Philippines and Vietnam belong to the top ten countries most affected by climatic extreme events worldwide (Germanwatch Climate Risk Index, 2009). The Philippines lies in the typhoon belt and an average of 20 typhoons pass through its boundaries annually, killing hundreds and destroying property. For example, in October 2010 typhoon Megi damaged US$ 44 million of agricultural products and facilities while typhoon Ketsana caused $130 million damage in the agriculture sector in 2009. The latter typhoon also caused $800 million of damage to Vietnam. Smallholder farmers are already among the most vulnerable sector of society to weather extremes and future climate change will likely increase both the number and intensity of weather extremes such as drought, flooding and storms. It is therefore necessary to raise their resilience and adaptive capacities in order to sustain and improve livelihoods and reduce the risks of smallholders falling deeper into poverty owing to current and future weather extremes.
The project is expected to assess sustainable land management options including agroforestry systems for adaptation to extreme climate events by smallholder farmers of Southeast Asia.

item.title: Exploring resilience to climate variability of Faidherbia albida to enable informed decision in promoting Evergreen Agriculture in the face of climate changes in Malawi
item.description: Malawi faces many social, economical and environmental problems, which are threatening sustainable livelihoods of family households and their environment. Agroforestry is seen as one of the avenues for increasing tree planting on farmland for various goods and services in Malawi. Faidherbia albida is one of the key agroforestry species commonly retained by smallholders in maize cropping systems in lowlands areas of eastern and southern Africa to provide nutrients for maize production. It is widely promoted as an option for adaptation of smallholder maize cropping systems to climate change, irrespective of agroecological setting. Based on few trees strong groundwater dependence of F. albida has previously been demonstrated for adult trees (Roupsard et al., 1999). A simulation study by Stave et al (2005) found that F. albida seedlings were adversely affected by moisture deficits under the rapid decline of water table and rainfall. They reported that F. albida behaves like a near obligate phreatophyte. This is an indication that F. albidia needs contact with ground water to thrive. That is probably why high densities of F. albida are found along river banks compared to upland and low land plains. If this is the case, can we promote F albida in areas where ground water is not available? Therefore, there is a dire need to understand the hydrological preferences, under natural conditions in space and time.

item.description: This activity seeks to review, revise and repackage a toolbox for landscape level assessment and planning for REDD+ and REALU. ICRAF has developed a set of tools and methods through the ASB Partnership and the RUPES programmes over the years. The ASB methods include Time average Carbon stock, opportunity cost estimation and land use change analysis approaches for application along tropical forest margins. Some of our methods are already widely used for example, The World Bank ASB Manual for estimating opportunity cost used by The Forest Carbon Partnership Facility FCPF in the training of country teams. . We plan to test these methodologies and those of others, and further refine as necessary for eventual use in landscape approaches to REDD at various land use planning scales . Further, we plan to develop tools for nesting baselines, additionality and leakage as we consider these as the main challenges for switching from REDD to reducing emissions from all land usesREALU or AFOLU accounting.

item.title: Mitigation of climate change in agriculture, including development of land health information systems and capacity building (2012-13)
item.description: Quantification of soil carbon stock baselines and changes is critical for both management of global climate change and sustainable soil management. However, carbon monitoring and verification schemes are currently based on modelling alone or measurement systems that are unpractical to implement at landscape scales. Each step of measuring soil carbon has associated errors, which propagate through to the final estimate of carbon stocks over an area. There are also different ways of expressing soil carbon stocks relative to soil mass and per unit soil volume. Having a good understanding of the uncertainties and propagation of errors is critical for knowing the limits, cost and feasibility of detecting changes in carbon stocks over time.

This research gap needs to be filled because it is important to understand the dynamics of GHG fluxes in tropical soils and their contributions to the total GHG emissions of tropical agricultural systems. item.title: Climatic determinants of genotypic adaptation characterized for contrasted historical normal periods (wet, dry, current) across the entire WA SAT; Updated agroclimatic metrics produced
item.description: Continental West Africa offers the most striking, multi-decadal climate change clues on record, with historical evidence of rainfall decrease magnitudes comparable to those proposed under anthropogenic climate change (Traore et al., 2007; Haussmann et al., 2012). Yet, assessments of climate change impacts on food security generally prioritize long-term yield projections driven by GCM outputs subject to high uncertainty, limited downscalability, and simulated by crop models where regional agro-biodiversity, (a)biotic stress patterns, physiological traits of importance and management practices (inter alia) are poorly represented. Over the past 3 decades, ICRISAT and its partners have assembled a ca. 40,000 station-years dataset of ground rainfall records for West Africa, and contributed to the collation of various historical multi-environments trial datasets for maize, millet, peanut and sorghum, some of which have been documented in the agro-trials online database. Our hypotheses are: i/ that historical trial data from the region can support the calibration of 20 representative ecotypes in 3 crop models; ii/ that models can simulate yield probabilities consistent with published agricultural statistics from the region; iii/ that significant yield differences can be modeled for contrasted (dry, wet) climate baselines; iv/ that improved representation of regional agro-biodiversity, physiology, stresses and management reduces simulated yield differences compared to published climate change impact studies.

item.title: Modelling of household level adaptation strategies in agro-pastoral systems of East Africa (Genesis reversed)
item.description: The actual impacts of climate change on agricultural systems that are experienced in developing countries will depend on location and adaptive capacity. But adapting to and coping with a changing climate are not infinitely plastic and there are places where it is likely that climate change will alter agroecological conditions to extents beyond the coping range, buffering capacity and viability of known adaptation measures. In such places, it may well be that livelihood options will have to change. Jones and Thornton (2009) point to the possibility of one such climateinduced livelihood transition in the mixed croplivestock rainfed aridsemiarid systems of Africa, altering the relative emphasis that agropastoralists currently place on the crop and livestock components of the farming system in favour of livestock. In these systems, cropping may become increasingly risky and marginal, perhaps leading to increased dependence on livestock keeping or increasing diversification into nonagricultural activities and migration to urban areas. Such areas may, to all intents and purposes, and quot;flipand quot; from a mixed system to a predominantly rangelandbased system: some 730,000 km2 of SSA may be at risk of such flipping, of which about 16% is located in areas within 3 hoursand apos; travel time of a population centre with more than 250,000 people, a proxy for and quot;good accessibility to marketsand quot; (Jones and Thornton, 2009). In a plus five degree world, the transition zone increases in size to 6 some 1.2 million km2, about 5% of the land area of SSA (Thornton et al., 2011). Moreover, with such warming, the proportion of this transition zone that is in areas of high accessibility increases to about 50%. Such conditions would mean considerable loss of cropland in SSA (cropping would become too risky in about 35% of the mixed rainfed aridsemiarid systems); and increasing amounts of this land would be in the hinterlands of large urban areas with already high population densities. This could be prevented by investments in adaptation creating the right environment for technology change and uptake. The project reported on here was set up as a test of the hypothesis that sedentary farmers who currently keep livestock in these transition zones or hotspots may ultimately be forced to increase their reliance on livestock and eventually to adopt nomadic pastoralism in the future. The hypothesis cannot of course be tested directly at this time (these future conditions do not yet exist in these hotspots), but we attempt to test the hypothesis first by understanding how farming systems in these zones have been changing in the recent past, and second by evaluating what the impacts of these changes, and further changes in the same direction, may be on household incomes and food security in the coming decades. Field surveys were used for the first part, and household modelling work for the second.

This is designed to be one input into a broader study that will identify policies and institutional measures that would support and guide the transition to nomadic pastoralism with minimal social, economic and political disruptions.

item.title: Quantification of the costs of adaptation of livestock systems to climate change
item.description: We assess the impacts of rising temperatures and changing precipitation patterns on all major crops and rangeland with the global vegetation-crop model LPJmL. Global average yields for most crops are reduced by 3-16%. Yields for maize, sugar beet and grass are increased by 3-4%. We use a an existing livestock classification scheme consisting of 8 livestock production systems (LPS) for ten world regions and six livestock product types. LPS are characterized by feed requirements per unit output, feed mix, and rangeland use. Ruminant meat and milk are mainly produced in rangeland-based or mixed systems, while pork, chicken and eggs exclusively come from industrial and smallholder systems. In most regions, feeding efficiencies are higher in mixed systems than in rangeland-based systems. (focus less on this as this is covered in our paper, and expand the next paragraph which is juicy) With the global land use model MAgPIE we explore how a shift in livestock production towards systems with higher feeding efficiencies can contribute to climate change adaptation. Without changes in livestock production, additional investments in crop productivity increase and land expansion will increase total agricultural production costs, due to climate change, by about 3% (i.e. 145 billion US$) in 2045. In Middle East/North Africa production costs will rise by about 16%, and in South Asia by about 9%. Shifts in livestock production systems can reduce the costs of climate change adaptation, reduce regional expansion of agricultural land, and, hence, the pressure on tropical forests.

item.title: Development and/or adaptation of suitable household models for studying risk management in farming systems
item.description: Risk management in household models is poorly represented. The rational behind this activity is to improve risk management routines in household models, with the objective of improving our assessments of how different types of farming systems can cope and manage climate variability. This project includes the following activities: 1. Short literature review will be performed on current and past approaches of modelling risk in uncertain environments, both for agronomic and ecological systems 2. Based on literature and the focus of CCAFS a short list of key risk indicators will be formulated 3. Generic prototype of risk modelling framework will be developed. Characteristics of this framework are: a. Complexity of framework matches data coming available through on-going CCAFS survey work. b. Produces stochastic realizations over time of: i. Key state variables of the systems (e.g. food available, cash available, soil C). ii. Other key indicators form the list of indicators produced in under item 2, e.g. food security, income, diet diversity. iii. Produces model output in relation to the thresholds defined for the key indicators defined under item 2. c. Uses a generic modular approach, which allows flexible use for different systems. d. Includes a setup to study progressive adaption options over time. e. Includes a setup for studying greenhouse gas mitigation options. 4. Prototype and approach used are evaluated in one the CCAFS sites; at the moment testing is foreseen for Makueni, Kenya.

item.description: Livestock are considered pathway out of poverty for poor smallholder farmers in the developing world. The production of livestock in mixed extensive and intensive croplivestock and pastoral grazing systems worldwide generates both positive and negative impacts on the environment. This creates a challenge to promote livestock production systems which can concurrently provide economic benefits that foster social development while ensuring environmental sustainability. In the developing world there is increasing interest in payment for environmental services (PES) as an instrument for environmental management that can also generate impact on poverty reduction particularly in rural areas. To date, there are few examples of PES targeting livestock keepers. This study assesses the potential of payment for environmental services in livestock inclusive agricultural production systems in developing countries, assesses the potential of payments for environmental services (PES) in various livestock inclusive farming systems in the developing world.

item.title: A framework for upscaling climate change adapatation and mitigation options
item.description: Investment in agriculture has increased in the last years, as the thrust of food security and environmental protection have become essential pillars of R4D strategies (World Bank 2007, Herrero et al 2010). Prudent use of limited resources is essential to ensure that the maximum gains from agricultural and NRM investments are obtained. This requires that resources are targeted in a rational way to the regions, sectors and production systems of the world that have the highest potential to achieve the triple wins of poverty reduction, environmental protection and food security. At the same time this requires a framework for targeting and scaling-out a variety of existing interventions for removing production constraints and protecting natural resources (mitigating climate change, promoting resource use efficiencies of water, soils, land and others). Farmers, service providers, policy makers and others supporting the agricultural sector, often have to make difficult choices between the different strategies to invest in and implement. All too often, short-term gains, which have an impact on household security in the near future, are chosen over options that can help to ensure the long-term sustainability of farming systems, such as prudent stewardship of soils and other natural resources. There are real needs and opportunities for well-targeted research to improve the livelihoods of farmers by addressing resource constraints. Priority setting of intervention packages for increasing productivity and improving resource use-efficiency of farming systems. Priority setting of intervention packages and policies for adapting to, and mitigating climate change. Understanding the out-scaling potential of different packages of interventions (across landscapes, production systems and others) Improving the quantification of the impacts of different interventions on different dimensions of farming systems and agricultural landscapes A better understanding and quantification of the mitigation potential of different mitigation strategies in farming systems.

item.title: Organising and amp; conducting training courses for staff from National Met. Services (NMS) and NARES in use of climate data and dialogues with farmers to increase awareness of farmers needs (links to activities in 2.1 in India)
item.description:
Climate information, including historical and real-time, plays an important role in planning and management of agricultural operations. When properly integrated with the decision making process, climate information has the potential to moderate the risk and vulnerability of agricultural systems to variable climatic conditions especially in semi-arid tropics where productivity and profitability of agriculture is directly influenced by within and between the season variability in rainfall. The need for such integration is more important now than ever due to the growing concern about the climate change and its impacts on agriculture.
Historically, meteorological organizations have collected and are maintaining huge databases of climatic information. But, very little effort has gone to turn this data into useful products that can be used by research and developmental programs. To a large extent this is constrained by complex nature of the agricultural systems and lack of appropriate tools to properly quantify the relationships between climate and agricultural production. Recent advances in our understanding of the agricultural systems coupled with those in the computing technology resulted in the development of a number of tools and methods that are extremely useful in conducting a detailed analysis on the soil-plant-climate systems. Unfortunately, use of these tools in most developing countries is limited by non-availability of required skills. This activity is aimed at enhancing the skills of researchers and extension agents in using the tools to better understand the variability and trends in climate, understanding the risks associated with the uncertainty in seasonal rainfall and develop appropriate management options that reduce risk and assist in capitalizing the opportunities. Climate information includes seasonal climate forecasts.

item.title: Collect bio-physical and household data from BM sites, ICRISAT CCAFS sites, ICRISAT village level studies in India and WA, and SLP project sites for integrated assessment of climate change and adaptation with Tradeoff Analysis model (linked to activities 1.1 and amp; 2.1)
item.description: IPCC and some recent studies at the sub-continental scale for CCAFS study regions indicate the importance of assessing the effects of climate change and possible adaptation strategies at the agricultural system and/or household level, rather than focusing on aggregated results that hide a large amount of variability. However, addressing impacts of climate change and adaptation in the context of small-scale, semi-subsistence agriculture raises special challenges. High data demands including site-specific bio-physical and economic data are an important constraint. Another drawback is that projections of climate change and simulations of the effects on crop and livestock productivity come with a high degree of variability and associated uncertainties depending on the climate models and methodologies used. The development and application of relatively simple and reliable methods for ex ante evaluation of adaptation strategies at the household and agricultural system levels are needed to provide timely assessments of the potential impacts in the context of climate change. In this CCAFS activity we develop and apply a new approach to impact assessment, the Tradeoff Analysis model for Multi-Dimensional impact assessment (TOA-MD), which simulates technology adoption and associated economic, environmental and social outcomes in a heterogeneous farm population for a regional impact assessment. The methodology uses the kinds of survey, experimental and modeled data that are typically available in countries where semi-subsistence systems are important, combined with future socio-economic scenarios based on new scenario pathway concepts being developed by the climate change and impact assessment modeling communities.
