item.title: Develop new germplasm catalogues on existing and released cassava germplasm
item.description: Cassava is a key staple crop in Sub-Saharan Africa and other food insecure areas in the world. The crop is perceived to still produce some yield (roots as starchy staple, leaves as leafy vegetable) in adverse conditions (i.e. poor soils, drought, heat). However, the genetic variability within the cassava family is very large, and so is the response to adverse conditions, to water and nutrient inputs, and to pest and disease pressure. Over the past years, major pest and disease outbreaks have threatened cassavaand apos;s role as a key food security crop in SSA. Pest and disease (vectors) are likely to further increase with climate change. There is a need to map the cassava germplasm diversity in relation to its response to environmental (biotic and abiotic) stresses, so as to predict the impact of climate change and mitigate potential impact by pre-emptively preparing robust germplasm to cope with adverse conditions.

item.title: Assess risks and test strategies for adaptation to significant crop biotic threats due to climate change
item.description: Plant disease and pest outbreaks have led to major food security crises in Sub-Saharan Africa over the past decades. Examples are the outbreak of cassava mosaic virus (CMV), cassava brown streak virus (CBS), and banana xanthomonas wilt (BXW), just to name a few. These pest and disease outbreaks are often caused by changes in insect population dynamics, either because they are the agent acting as the disease vector or causing direct physical damage to the plant, or because natural insect enemies have not been able to control the insect pest/vector. The population dynamics and behaviour of pests are strongly depending on climatic conditions (i.e. temperature, humidity, winds) and by the presence and condition of host plants that are affected by climate conditions as well. In this activity, we try to understand and model the impact of climate variability and change on majore pest and diseases.

item.ccafs:objective: Understand the effect of climate variability on major pest/disease dynamics, which can be used by crop breeders and producers to build the adaptive capacity/activities.

item.title: Develop new knowledge and tools to assess potential emission reductions from various crop systems and technology options to improve productivity and enhance food security
item.description: Understading GHG stocks and fluxes are key to creating insight into the impact of crop managment practices and land use changes on climate change. Quantifying below- and above-ground carbon stocks, as well as green house gas emissions related to fertilizer use and post-harvest processign and handling are key. Whereas major progress has been made on quantification protocols for above and below ground carbon stocks and fluxes, much less insight and tools are available when it comes to the temporal and spatial dynamics of input use and post-harvest processing. For example, during the fermentation of coffee and cocoa, supposedly large amounts of methane is emitted, which is a powerful GHG gas. Trying to quantify the latter fluxes and building that into tools that can be used by producers and the cocoa/coffee industry woudl be very useful, since carbon-neutral products are on demand.

item.title: Assessment of cocoa and coffee based agricultural systems for carbon sequestration potential to mitigate risk of climate change and enhance food security
item.description: Recent studies have shown that coffee and cocoa smallholder production systems are vulnerable to climate change. Important changes in crop suitability are predicted in the current major growing areas. To cope with climate change, farmers will have to adapt their practices (e.g. climate-smart shade systems). These adaptation practices will impact the carbon footprint per unit area and per unit product produced. There are trade-offs in terms of adaptation/mitigation at both plot and landscape level. IITA, CIAT, UGOE, WITS, NARS, NGOs are currently teaming up to quantify and understand the mitigation and adaptation potential of shaded and non-shaded, intensified and low-input cocoa and coffee systems. We will also involve the private sector partners, who are increasingly interested in certifying sustainable (and increasingly carbon neutral) products for their consumers.

item.ccafs:objective: To quantify, understand, and communicate adaptation/mitigation trade-offs for smallholders, NARS, extension officers, and the private sector partners, so that they can make informed decisions on their best practices in terms of profitability and sustainability

item.title: Assessingclimatechangeimpactsandadaptationpathwaysinmajorricegrowingareaswithspecificvulnerabilities
item.description: This activity addresses the adaptation of rice production systems through diverse approaches ranging from field level technologies to policy recommendations. Geographic emphasis is given to mega-deltas of S and SE Asia. Rice production in delta regions such as the Mekong in Vietnam and the Ganges-Brahmaputra in Bangladesh is of outmost importance at regional, national and trans-national scale. Due to the direct impacts of sea level rise, delta regions are among the most vulnerable environments to climate change. Recent development in rice breeding and crop management offer distinct prospects to cope with of sea rise and other climate change impacts. Improved resiliencies to flooding and salinity have been among the key traits integrated into new rice varieties. Improved heat resilience is the focus of newly launched breeding program at IRRI, so that that targeted dissemination in heat-prone environments may in future avert projected yield losses. Water-saving techniques have been developed to reduce irrigation requirement, but these approaches also offer innate opportunities for coping with drought while maintaining high yield potentials. However, dissemination of these technological options requires special outreach to rice farmers in the areas affected. Previously, farmers have often been reluctant to adopt changes in farming practice, e.g. modified irrigation patterns, as these options have been perceived to carry detrimental effects or certain risks to yield performance. Thus, it will be crucial to strive for farmers participation in fine-tuning given technologies to site-specific conditions and identify synergies to agriculture development programs conducted by national agencies.

item.title: Promoting mitigation projects in rice-based production systems in South and Southeast Asia (preparation phase)
item.description: This activity will promote GHG mitigation in rice production through assessing the feasibility of water saving techniques and providing guidelines for implementation. The Alternate-Wetting-and-Drying technique will be assessed in different rice-growing regions of Vietnam and the Philippines by considering differences in natural and agronomic settings, e.g. the distinction between gravity and pump irrigation. However, changes in water management entail manifold implications on carbon and nitrogen cycles that have to be elucidated in adequate field experiments to avoid eventual drawbacks caused by a wide-ranging adoption. Moreover, the project will develop guidelines for Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRV) as well as innovative approaches for recording emissions in situ. These guidelines and techniques will integrate necessary information for reliable quantification of emission savings that can be used by future mitigation projects. In addition to water saving, changes in crop residue management offer the greatest mitigation potential in rice production. Rice straw is often burned in Asia entailing considerable GHG emissions. Methane and nitrous oxide are formed due to incomplete combustion of straw, but the quantification of these emissions can only be done in a broad approximation without any empirical evidence for the specifics of rice straw burning. In turn, a more elaborate approach for computing baseline emissions from straw burning is a pre-requisite for any conceivable CDM methodology. This activity will further address the involvement of female household members into mitigation projects. As for climate change adaptation, distinctively female perceptions in decision making may be used to popularize changes in crop management.

item.title: Validation of simulationmodelsonyieldsandemissionsinriceproductionsystems
item.description: Abiotic stresses such as salt, heat, drought, cold and submergence coinciding with critical development stages are the major threats to sustainable rice productivity throughout the world. Farmers can adapt to these trends by growing stress tolerant cultivars, by shifting their sowing dates, and by adopting site-specific management strategies to optimize resource use efficiency and reduce water use. These adaptation strategies, however, require a holistic knowledge on cause-symptom relationships in rice management that can only be accomplished by modeling approaches. Likewise, modeling approaches are needed to achieve mitigation of GHG emissions without yield losses. Due to pre-dominant flooding of soils, rice production systems exhibit specific features in terms of yield performance and element cycling as compared to other (upland) production systems. Thus, simulation models for yields and emissions have to be either developed specifically for rice (e.g. ORYZA2000) or require specific modules and validation procedures (as done for DNDC). These validated model versions can then be used in climate impact assessments.

item.description: Researchers working on this proposed project would contribute to improving food security and well being of sub-Saharan rural households trapped in cycles of poverty and vulnerability that are exacerbated by climate change. They would help develop practices that integrate aquaculture into diversified food production systems and enhance management of water use for aquaculture as well as improve small-scale irrigation. Participants would conduct a scientific assessment of the potential for sustaining high water productivity, improving capacity for design, developing and implementing approaches for enhancing water use, and providing guidance for water use by integrating aquaculture and small scale irrigation in the Chinyanja Triangle in the lower Zambezi River basin. The basin encompasses the Southern and Central Provinces of Malawi, the Eastern Province of Zambia and the Tete Province of Mozambique. Partners include Chancellor College of Malawi, Bunda College University of Malawi, the International Water Management Institute, the Malawi Department of Irrigation, the Malawi Department of Fisheries and the Universitaet Osnabruck.

item.ccafs:objective: On the one hand, research on multiple water use practices for the sub-Saharan smallholding, focused largely on crop and livestock integration, has shown improvements in farm-level water productivity and the benefits of onfarm water harvesting and storage to cope with uncertain water supplies. So has research on farm-levellAA technologies demonstrated benefits to household food security, child nutrition and assured production during drought years. On the other hand, broader catchment- and basin-scale research on water resources allocation and management demonstrate the virtues of integrated water resources management that emphasize benefits sharing so that geographically-dispersed users get an equitable share of water while ensuring that the environmental flows are maintained for sustainable use of the water resources. The project will bridge these research efforts and achievements by focusing work at the catchment level where up-scaling of farm-level practices raises issues of water resources availability and allocation that can benefit from down-scaling of research findings on these issues commonly conducted at the broader basin level. The project will also apply participatory methods to engage stakeholders in adaptive water management in the context of dispersed, formal and informal small-scale irrigation systems.

item.title: Develop and implement basin-wide climate change adaptations in Lake Chilwa, Malawi, in support of the NAPA by enhancing the capacity of communities to adopt sustainable livelihood and natural resource management practices
item.description: According to recent United Nations climate change profiles, Malawi is predicted to experience higher temperatures and precipitation falling in a shorter period with heavier rainfall. Malawi has already experienced a variety of dry spells, droughts, intense rainfalls, riverine floods and flash floods. Researchers working on this project would aim to secure the livelihoods of some 1.5 million people and enhance the resilience of the natural resource base in the Lake Chilwa Basin. In order to maintain food security, economic and social benefits of agriculture and natural resources in the face of known climate variability and anticipated climate change, researchers would work to develop and implement basin-wide climate change adaptation strategies that will enhance the resilience of communities. They would work to strengthen local and district institutions to better manage natural resources and build resilience to climate change. They would facilitate and help build cross-basin and cross-sectoral natural resources management and planning policy for climate change throughout the basin. Researchers would also work to improve household and enterprise capacity to adapt, and finally, they would work to mitigate the effects of climate change through improved forest management and governance. The Malawi Government recently approved the National Adaptation Programme of Action for climate change. The efforts of the WorldFish Center and partners would be complimentary to the efforts of the national government. Partners would include Leadership for Environment and Development (LEAD), the Forestry Research Institute of Malawi and the National Herbarium and Botanical Gardens of Malawi.

item.description: Catfish farmers in Vietnams Mekong River Delta are barely scraping by. They operate on the tightest of profit margins 3% to 5% in a good year and deal with a highly volatile, boom-and-bust export market. One extreme weather event like Typhoon Linda, which struck Southern Vietnam in 1997, can wipe out infrastructure, road access to markets everything. item.title: Assessing the impact of appropriate risk management financial packages on householdand apos;s asset portfolios in Bangladesh
item.description:
Index insurance is an innovative financial product that helps rural households manage large covariate shocks to agricultural income. Current research is increasingly showing that an effective risk management strategy in the face of climate change will require a combination of indexed insurance, savings and credit and that the correct combination of these three financial products will likely depend on the nature of climatic shocks and rural financial markets
If rural communities have access to such risk management tools they can increase the degree to which they are able to withstand climate risks. This in turn is likely to increase their investments in technologies in which the return is dependent on the climate. The ultimate effect of insurance on the resilience of rural households is thus an empirical question that is likely to vary depending on the situation being considered.
item.ccafs:deliverableTitle: Structural model defined and programmed
Basic calibrations and predictions made using existing data and results of RCTs
item.ccafs:objective: This research will use the latest techniques in structural modeling and randomized control trials (RCTs) to design a behavioral model that allows us to make predictions about the likely impact of index insurance and other financial instruments on a rural communities resilience to climate related risk. Specifically this research will fund work on designing and calibrating a structural model of household behavior that incorporates: (i) a households decision to purchase insurance; (ii) household investments in risky agricultural technologies, and (iii) household consumption decisions. This model will allow us to generate predictions on: a) optimal design of index insurance products, b) the optimal combination of financial products required to manage climate risk and c) the likely impact of these products on agricultural investments and ultimately household welfare.

item.title: Low Emission Development Strategies (LEDS) in agriculture
item.description: It is now widely recognized that natural resource use in many developing countries, from crop production to deforestation, is responsible for the bulk of greenhouse gas emissions. We also know that in many countries, it is the agriculture and forestry sectorsnot industry or transportthat provide low-cost mitigation opportunities. As countries experience economic growth and choose among the available development pathways, they are in a favourable position to adopt natural resource use technologies and production practices characterized by low GHG emissions. Rather than embedding high emissions practices in their development and intervene on emissions reduction at a later stage, they can utilize Low Emissions Development Strategies (LEDS).

item.title: Study on the economic viability of climate change mitigation through the use biochar
item.description:
Work completed by IFPRI and collaborators in Ghana, indicates that while the potential for carbon sequestration through carbon accumulation in agricultural soils is a substantial reality, its quantification presents considerable challenges. In order to compute the amount of carbon sequestered, one has to create a baseline of soil carbon for a period of 15 20 years and this requires predicting farmers agricultural decisions for the same period. Soil organic carbon content is highly dependent on crop choices, input usage, and on agronomic practices implemented, and it is particularly difficult to predict smallholder farmers choices for long periods of time. In fact, poor farmers have a very short planning horizon and decisions about input usage and agronomic practices are dependent on market vagaries, family size, and other hard-to-predict factors. There is, though, one practice in the area of study that is recurrent, widespread, and very predictable: slash and burn. This practice is used to clear a plot of land after a few years of fallow. Slash and burn saves labor, kills pests, and returns a small amount of minerals to the soil. However, the transformation of woody fallow growth into biochar, which directly avoids CO2 emissions and could be used as a soil amendment, could be a viable alternative to current practices.
Biochar is charcoal produced from biomass using an anaerobic process called pyrolysis and its chemical characteristics make it particularly valuable. The form of carbon present in biochar is thought to be stable in the soil for hundreds of years. Furthermore, biochar can increase soil water- and nutrient-holding capacity with direct positive effects on yields, particularly in nutrient-deficient soils. The stability of the biochar carbon, the immediate reduction of CO2 emissions, and the positive effects on yields, substantially reduce problems related to permanence and MRV that limit the viability of other climate change mitigation methods in agriculture.

item.title: Identify the set of global agriculture models to be included in the AGMIP agricultural model intercomparison work, with specific model inputs and outputs that the model inter comparison exercise will be based on. Representative Agricultural Pathways will also be identified.
item.description: AgMIP is a distributed climate-scenario simulation exercise for historical model intercomparison and future climate change conditions with participation of multiple crop and agricultural economics modeling groups around the world. The goals of AgMIP are to improve substantially the characterization of risk of hunger and world food security due to climate change and to enhance adaptation capacity in both developing and developed countries. AgMIP will significantly enhance information (including uncertainty estimates) to guide policymakers regarding risk of hunger, world food security, and agricultural adaptation. A key aspect is to create capacity-building partnerships among agricultural crop and economic modelers around the world, enhancing the ability of each nation to evaluate current and future climate impacts and adaptations. As part of the above program, this secific activity aims to establish a methodological and procedural foundation for the systematic comparison and improvement of global and regional land use, production and trade models used for analysis of climate change impact, as well as mitigation and adaptation in the agricultural sector. It will involve coordinating and facilitating intercomparison of both regional and global agricultural market models being used for climate change impact and adaptation research. Achieving these objectives will include participating in the AgMIP cross-cutting themes to build collaborations between climate scientists, crop modelers and economic modeling groups to improve methods and procedures that allow crop model simulations to be used as inputs into economic models.

item.title: Dissemination of gender-CC training materials; gender methods training activities organized in 3 regions. TOR for gender technical advisory group developed and new cross-theme gender and pro-poor action research designed.
item.description:
CCAFS recently developed a gender strategy and is seeking to develop a technical advisory group that will help design and implement new and innovative gender-targeted research approaches across CCAFS sites in 3 regions. This research will build upon recent gender-focused research tools developed by CCAFS-FAO and IFPRI-USAID. CCAFS has undertaken some initial participatory gender-related research across all the CCAFS sites to date, and we would like to build upon this to delve deeper into intra-household issues, for example. CCAFS is also very committed to doing action research, where NGO, government or private sector partners (or a combination) are implementing interventions aimed at enhanced resilience to climate and other changes, and the research component seeks to enhance the impact of those interventions.
Two key research issues that have been seen as critical to date for CCAFS include: 1) access to and use of, improved weather and climate-related information/forecasts, along with the associated agricultural practices and technologies knowledge needed to make best use of the forecasts; 2) what are the climate-smart agricultural practices in the different regions, and if and how they will be beneficial to women as well as men (and enhance food security).
CCAFS has begun to build capacity of research teams in baselines and some initial gender-CC research training of regional gender research teams; we would also like to begin to scale that out together with partners like FAO, CARE and others.

item.title: Mapping risks and opportunities for targeting appropriate crop and livestock adaptation strategies in East Africa
item.description: Climate change will alter the distribution and intensity of the biotic and abiotic stresses that affect farming systems in East Africa. Erratic rainfall patterns, temperature fluctuation, land erosion , degrading soil quality, sensitivity to diseases and variation in biodiversity are examples of current climate change manifestations which will affect important livelihoods systems and food production. The activity builds on the outcomes of the regional science workshop in June 2012. The project will identify linkages between biophysical, environmental and socio-economic nature of risks and opportunities brought by climate change in major farming systems and agro-ecological zones that are vulnerable to climate in East Africa for targeting adaptation interventions and technologies to appropriate biophysical and socioeconomic environments. The study sites will include the existing CCAFS sites in the region.

item.description: The activity builds on the outcomes of the regional science workshop and the regional capacity training workshop on using climate scenarios and analogues for designing adaptation options in East Africa. While climate scenarios and climate analogues are useful tools for identifying potential adaptation pathways, the use of these tools to inform national adaptation planning processes in East Africa has been limited. The overall aim of the study is to scale-up use of climate scenarios and spatial analogues to strengthen national adaptation plans and policies, and facilitate farmer-to-farmer exchange of knowledge to enhance adaptation learning in East Africa. The study will be implemented in three CCAFS sites representing different farming systems across East Africa: Nyando and Wote in Kenya (Kenya), and Lushoto (Tanzania). Already under the Farms of the Future project, a farmer -to - farmer learning visit was undertaken in Lushoto, Tanzania, in May 2012. The objective of the visit was to expose farmers from the learning site to potential adaptation and coping strategies.

item.title: Quantification of GHG emissions to inform mitigation interventions in East African agricultural systems
item.description: The project will build capacity and collect information for characterizing GHG emissions and identify mitigation potentials of typical agricultural systems in EA. It will build on the CCAFS sampling frames and the Land Degradation Surveillance Framework (LDSF) developed by ICRAF at few selected sites. In addition, the study will make use of existing household data to select farm types and within those, cropping activities to identify promising mitigation options. Cropping activities will be selected on the basis of regional importance in terms of contribution to incomes and food security. After selecting cropping options, on-farm trials will be established where gas fluxes and agronomic data measurements will be conducted. The specific activites will include: i) Determining the most convenient/cost effective and reliable instruments for quantification of GHG emissions thereby considering infrastructural constraints, ii) Designing procedures and protocols for selecting case studies within the CCAFS sampling frames in EA, iii) Training researchers and technicians to measure GHG fluxes and farming system characterization (e.g. crop performance, soils, livelihoods), iv) Establishing on-farm experiments to measure GHG emissions, productivity, profitability and social acceptability through farmers interviews, and v) Combining data, analyzing and performing model simulations to identify promising mitigation options.

item.description: With rapid population growth and resulting demand for food and feeds, GHG emissions have risen in South Asia. Agriculture and livestock sectors contribute on GHG emissions. Lowland rice cultivation,predominant in many parts of South Asia, is a mjor source of methane and nitrous oxide gases. A large flux of methane is attributed through livestock. item.title: Linking knowledge to action through scenario building at the regional level in South Asia
item.description: Agricultural production and food security under climate change requires us to question what is needed in terms of policies, institutions and governance to support these changes. A powerful approach to help decision makers start addressing transformational challenges that climate change brings is to engage and build capacity with a diverse range of stakeholders from across the region to jointly develop future scenarios of possible development pathways . Scenarios help inform decision making under uncertainty through the development of a structured range of plausible futures, within which analyses of different policy and technical interventions can be undertaken. They also provide an effective mechanism for involving a range of both public and private sector stakeholders and for facilitating debate and communication among them. Qualitative and quantitative regional level scenarios will be developed by regional teams trained in this approach. This will help decision makers to make strategic regional policies on food security, agricultural development and climate-related issues as defined by key regional players.

item.title: Empowering rural women to adapt for food security in South Asia
item.description: Field-evidence shows that even vulnerable and poor women can play a pro-active role in adapting to climate change. Women are often in a better position to note certain environmental hazards and seek solutions to their problems where these affect their families directly. They use various strategies to address lack of drinking water, know which traditional seed varieties will withstand increased salinity or grow in water stress areas and which native trees should be protected for food and fodder. This type of knowledge is critical for developing efficient adaptation measures. Women leaders have the advantage of accessing government programmes, schemes and resources to help poor farmers adapt. Thus, training elected women leaders is of special advantage in helping communities adapt to climate change in South Asia.

item.title: Discussion paper analyzing the role of rural institutions in enabling adaptation to climate change in the agricultural sector (SEI)
item.description: The adverse effects of climate change will fall disproportionately on poor, resource deprived rural households. Small-scale agricultural producers are among the dominant groups in this demographic and are most vulnerable to climatic variability. Consequently, the front lines in the fight to adapt to changing climate lies with these households and the rural institutions that support them. We can define institutions as the humanly created formal and informal mechanisms that shape social and individual expectations, interactions, and behavior. They can be classified as falling into public (bureaucratic administrative units, and elected local governments), civic (membership and cooperative organizations), and private sectors (service and business organizations) (Uphoff and Buck 2007). Understanding the dynamics between these diverse institutions, how they react to upheavals in livelihood systems and their collective interactions with rural households is key to overcoming obstacles that prevent the sharing of information and resources that contribute to improved adaptive capacity. In many cases, adaptive pathways have already been developed; what is needed is investment or support for the appropriate rural institutions to incentivize producers and other market actors to change course.

item.title: Support to Participatory Social Return on Investment (PSROI) pilot studies in Vietnam and Lao PDR.
item.description: This activity represents a continuation of Theme 1 work (from 2011 work in EA and WA) in piloting the Social Return on Investment (SROI) framework for selecting and costing community based adaptations to climate change. Billions of dollars are allocated every year based on cost estimates of actions to cope with or benefit from the impacts of climate change. Costing is a complex process involving multiple actors with differing value systems and a spectrum of possible adaptation strategies and pathways. Current costing is dominated by top down approaches and subject to misallocation, with global funds not reaching where they are most needed by vulnerable communities. PSROI is an analytical costing framework which provides a structured framework for multi-stakeholder adaptation planning, including selection and valuation of appropriate adaptation pathways. The broader social, economic and ecological impacts of these interventions are explored and valued through participatory processes. PSROI is strength-based, building local capacity and generating stakeholder buy-in. The financial valuation generated provides an additional tool for examining and prioritising adaptation actions based on impact.

CIP has developed Insect Life Cycle Modeling (ILCYM) software which supports the development of process-based temperature-driven and age-stage structured insect phenology models and to apply these models for insect species distribution and risk mapping under different climate change scenarios. ILCYM is an open-source computer aided tool built on R-codes with a user friendly interface in Java computing language. It is linked to an uDig platform, which is a geographic information system (GIS), an application that contains basic tools for managing and mapping geographic information. To improve the software capacity in climate data interpolation and modeling and predicting changes in the regional distribution and abundance of insect pests new modules have to be integrated.

item.title: Phenology modeling and climate change risk assessments for the larger grain borer (Prostephanus truncatus) and the maize weevil (Sitophilus zeamais)
item.description: At the Third Annual CCAFS Science Workshop, Copenhagen, Denmark, 1-2 May 2012, emerging interest at different centers have been identified to study the effects of climate change on pests and diseases. Based on results of a scoping study requested by CCAFS and led by the Kansas State University in 2011, it is recommended that CG-centers and other stakeholders work together to assemble and evaluate a general platform for pest and disease risk assessments under climate change. The proposed work will help in filling data gaps on effects of changing climatic factors, particularly temperature, on key postharvest insect-pests (maize weevil and LGB), growth, development, grain damage and loss. Undertaking risk assessment and developing prediction tools for future post-harvest pests expansion of their range and intensity in relation to changing climate, will be of paramount importance to design integrated pest management strategy.

item.title: Pests and diseases research: interaction between soil beneficial microorganisms, mediating defense reactions to the attack of pod borers in cowpea, as influence by a range of water supply regimes from flooding to drought.
item.description:
This activity will address the interaction between soil beneficial microorganisms, mediating defense reactions to the attack of pod borers in cowpea.
Beneficial microorganisms can play a substantial role in enhancing yield production in cowpea (Ngakou et al., 2007). In particular, mycorrhiza and endophytic fungi can interact in eliciting defense reactions in response to attack by insect pests, and this model is being tested on cowpea pests such as the cowpea pod borer Maruca vitrata (Lepidoptera, Crambidae). On-going experiments have showed up to 62% larval mortality when pod borer larvae are fed with cowpea plant parts (leaves, flowers and pods), whose seeds have been inoculated with endophytic strains of the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana in pot experiments. We are currently co-inoculating cowpea seeds with mycorrhizal fungi, and preliminary observations indicate possible synergies between the two beneficial organisms. In view of the increased periods of erratic rainfall which either leads to drought or floods (or even a combination of them during the same cropping season), it becomes important to test these interaction in a range of gradients of water supply. The influence of these different degrees of water supply (and their changes over time) will be simulated both in rain-out shelters, and also in the open field by sequential plantings from the wet into the dry season (using irrigation facilities if needed).
item.ccafs:deliverableTitle: Technical report including: New knowledge about complex interactions between 1) two different and interacting beneficial soil microorganisms; 2) the cowpea plant; and 3) the legume pod borer, a cowpea pest, with regard to changing and erratic rainfall pattern

item.title: Collaborative project on vulnerability analysis with the Trust
item.description: Climate change is expected to significantly impact agriculture through reduced crop yields, increase in the prevalence of pests and diseases, and loss of associated agricultural biodiversity. Crop models are normally used to generate projections of future agricultural yields and determine impacts. However, crop models do not exist for every crop and thus cannot be used extensively. Here we use the EcoCrop model to predict suitability of 26 globally important food crops, parameterised based on both observational data and expert knowledge.

item.title: Linking Knowledge with Action through Regional Scenario Building
item.description: Agricultural production and food security under climate change requires us to question what is needed in terms of policies, institutions and governance to support these changes, rather than to maintain the status quo. A powerful approach to help decision makers start addressing transformational challenges that climate change brings is to engage and build capacity with a diverse range of stakeholders from across the region to jointly develop future scenarios of possible development pathways under different assumptions of policy and investment pathways. Scenarios help inform decision making under uncertainty through the development of a structured range of plausible futures, within which analyses of different policy and technical interventions can be undertaken. They also provide an effective mechanism for involving a range of both public and private sector stakeholders and for facilitating debate and communication among them. Qualitative and quantitative regional level scenarios will be developed by regional teams trained in this approach. This will help decision makers to make strategic regional policies on food security, agricultural development and climate-related issues as defined by key regional players.

item.title: Model Intercomparisons of major global models using ARC RCPs and SSPs as drivers
item.description: Quantitative models of economic behavior have become an important part of global efforts to understand the causes and consequences of climate change. The Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) is a major international effort to assess the state of global agricultural modeling and to understand climate impacts on the agricultural sector. The global economic modeling component of AgMIP has been engaging key global economic modelers in a cross-model scenario comparison exercise based on climate model runs and socioeconomic scenarios for the Fifth Assessment Report of the IPCC. Theme Leader 4.3 is co-leading this component, and the specific CCAFS activity is supporting the above. A total of 10 models are participating in the global reference scenario comparison. In terms of their representation of economic relationships, seven of these are general equilibrium models while four are partial equilibrium models. A set of six or more simulations have been developed to expose the models to a wide range of drivers. These are constructed on three orthogonal axes of socioeconomics, climate change and biofuels policies, with a simulation timeframe extending to 2050.

item.title: MarkSim version 2 and associated tools, development and testing; revision of MarkSim GCM with CMIP5 data
item.description: MarkSim is a third-order markov rainfall generator, first released in 2002, that is able to simulate the observed variance of rainfall in both tropical and temperate regions. It works from a large set of parameters based (in version 1s case) on a calibration dataset of some 10,000 stations worldwide that have in most cases more than 15 years of daily historical rainfall data. Climates were clustered into some 700 types, and some of the parameters of the MarkSim model calculated by regression from the cluster most representative of the climate point to be simulated. Since its release, the tool has been widely used in the agricultural modelling community, and it is now also being used in empirically downscaling the outputs from climate models to produce daily weather data that are characteristic of future climatologies that can then be fed to agricultural models to evaluate possible impacts in the future. Since 2002, another 30,000 stations of historical daily rainfall have been collected, and version 2 of MarkSim will make use of this greatly expanded calibration data set. See previous activity description for more detail on previous phases.

item.title: Soil profile characteristics database development and refinement, for use in agricultural impact modeling work
item.description: Computer simulation models are now being widely used for impact assessment studies and for supporting policy decisions at different temporal and spatial scales. However, for application of these models detailed data bases are required that cover large regional areas. Unfortunately, this information is rarely available. The International Soil Reference and Information Centre (ISRIC) has developed a series of detailed soil databases, early versions of which have been converted for use in agricultural impact model applications. Accurate soil data that represent local soil conditions are important for the simulation of the soil water and nitrogen balances, especially for rainfed conditions where water is limiting. Soil data can be extremely variable across space, and scaling up from point-based simulations to grid-based simulation provides considerable challenges related to input data. There is now a WISE Version 3.1 database, and converting this into model format would allow many more additional soil profiles to be utilized, that may be more representative of the local conditions.

item.title: Global Mapping of Intensive Livestock Production Systems
item.description: Population growth, urbanisation and changes in dietary preferences associated mostly with increasing wealth are driving massive increases in demand for livestock products. The implications of this rapid growth in demand and supply of animal source foods are manifold. Whilst presenting opportunities for many involved in the livestock sector, it also poses significant challenges in terms of threatening poor peoples livelihoods; introducing animal and public health risks; reducing the diversity of animal genetic resources; and imposing a strain on the environment. It is thus important to understand the driving forces behind the intensification and concentration of livestock production in order to determine where intensification is occurring now and to predict where it is likely to occur in the future. Such information can be used to guide research, development and policies that assist people in adapting to these changing circumstances and that help to mitigate the negative effects that may arise through such changing patterns of production.

item.title: Refinement of global cropland extent data layers
item.description: Reliable global data sets of cropland extent would seem to be a key resource for many different purposes. For example, the future agricultural potential of tropical areas will play a critical role in meeting the challenge of future food security. While crop yield can be estimated with some reliability using a limited sample of ground observations, reliable crop acreages and their spatial distribution are rarely available. Different remote sensing products are available, but comparison work (see, for example, Fritz et al. (2010), Comparison of global and regional land cover maps with statistical information for the agricultural domain in Africa, International Journal of Remote Sensing 31 (9), 2237-2256), indicates that some products do better in some places and some in others. The work here seeks to produce a hybrid product that combines the best of the available information.

The aim is to create a site that will facilitate greater levels of co-operation between modelling groups, data providers, funding organisations and stakeholder beneficiaries, in order to increase modelling research capacity to support food security and climate change initiatives. The purpose of the web site will be to serve the global research community by providing a resource, information and discussion centre that facilitates more and better quality research by the agricultural modelling and wider environmental and socio-economic research communities. It will also serve as a centre for contact between the scientific research community and policy development stakeholders at regional, national and international levels. The rationale for developing this web resource is the recognition of the need to facilitate greater up-take of modelling activities, particularly in developing countries, to support national capabilities to research food security and climate change impacts, mitigation and adaptation. There is further need to streamline the process by which new model activities are developed, and by which existing initiatives can be improved, to better support actions on improving food security and tackling climate change.

item.title: CCAFS Near-Term Climate Project
item.description: Climate information is used in agriculture and food security on a range of timescales, from days (weather), months (seasonal outlooks) to decades (climate change scenarios) (Hellmuth et al. 2011). Providing information on climate between seasonal and decadal timescales has proved difficult, falling into the period where traditional forecast skill dies away and the climate change signal is difficult to detect against natural variability. Yet much policy, planning and investment decision-making falls into this time horizon (Stafford-Smith et al. 2011). Both the seasonal forecasting community and the climate change scenario community have developed techniques and methods for provision and communication of climate infomation, as well as the use of climate information in impacts assessment, planning, risk mitigation, adaptation, etc. Decision-making on 1-10 year timescales may require a hybrid approach that draws on btoh traditions. Yet there has been little research on the climate information needs on these timescales, on methods that can provide the required information, or on how to use what will necessarily be uncertain information in planning and decision making.

item.title: G-Range (global rangeland model) development and testing
item.description: Temperate and tropical rangelands occur throughout the world and support the livelihoods of millions of livestock-owning households. Global change, such as climate change associated with a build-up of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gasses, is anticipated to alter the services that rangelands provide. One means of increasing the likelihood that households, enterprises, and land managers will be able to adapt to future changes is if future conditions can be anticipated. A method of anticipating future conditions is through using simulations, where inputs into the simulations are modified as predicted in change scenarios. A means of simulating future changes in rangelands across the globe is sought. While numerous grassland and rangeland simulation models have been developed, none is amenable to use directly in global simulations. The work here seeks to develop a process-based simulation model that is spatially explicit and of moderate complexity. The model will allow global analyses of native rangelands and the changes they may undergo.

item.title: Demonstrating a generic framework and tools for modeling resilience of farm households to climate related risk
item.description: The ability to model the impact of climate-related risk on rural households, and to evaluate the impacts of risk management interventions ex-ante, is a priority need within CCAFS Theme 2, and quot;Adaptation through Managing Climate Risk.and quot; However, a simple static approach to risk analysis is not adequate to account for the effects of antecedent conditions, or the time structure of climate and other stochastic drivers, on the risk that a rural household encounters; or the cumulative impact of risk on a householdand apos;s ability to meet its livelihood goals. This activity aims to develop a resilience framework and household modeling tools that will provide an advantage over simple, static approaches to risk analysis.

item.title: Quantification of regional scenarios using global integrated models
item.description: The development and use of scenarios functions as a platform for the exchange and application of knowledge and experience between CCAFS researchers and policy makers, privator sectors, NGOs and other societal actors. Because scenarios allow for the capturing of uncertainties and systems complexity in a coherent and plausible yet surprising and challenging fashion, scenarios are also a tool for generating shared engagement. The next step in the scenarios process is to explore the implications of these qualitative scenarios through quantigication using GEC and economic models that focus on food security assessment. The quantification of the scenarios will increase their credibility and plausibility and their usefulness as contexts for the testing of policies and strategies. Initially, the scenarios quantification will be done through the close collaboration of two modeling teams--a team working with the IMPACT model developed at IFPRI and a team working with the GLOBIOM model developed at IIASA.

item.title: Review of climate change communications and social learning in climate change
item.description: Phase 1: While a large body of literature is concerned with climate change communications and social learning in the developed world, less is available or applicable to the developing world. The differences between climate change communications approaches and social learning approaches should be articulated. Various approaches and tools are being developed and applied by the development community and the aim is to review the existing approaches, tools and decision aids that are applicable in this context, as well as the major stakeholders involved in the CCAFS target regions. The abilities of different communication tools to bring out stakeholders engagement in the exchange of perspectives on CCAFS issues should be a central consideration. Phase 2: In late 2011, CCAFS Theme 4 issued a call for proposals for people and organizations to help develop a CCAFS strategy on communication and social learning. IDS/IIED were selected for the review and contributed to the subsequent process of designing and facilitating a May 2012 workshop in Addis Ababa. Drawing on the IDS/IIED review of current climate change communications and social learning approaches, tools and decision aids, as well as the Addis Workshop, we want to identify the main strengths and weaknesses in targeting specific stakeholders, as well as the gaps that will inform a CCAFS strategy to engage in this area. We are interested in different kinds of communication approaches, tools and decision aids for different levels of stakeholders (such as farmers, community groups, local governments, etc.). IIED and IDS will collaborate on this project and work closely with CCAFS, ILRI-KMIS and the mechanisms of engagement that are being established.

item.title: Sponsoring of participants for AgMIP workshop
item.description: The Agricultural Model Intercomparison and Improvement Project (AgMIP) is a distributed climate-scenario simulation exercise for historical model intercomparison and future climate change conditions with participation of multiple crop and world agricultural trade modeling groups around the world. The goals of AgMIP are to improve substantially the characterization of risk of hunger and world food security due to climate change and to enhance adaptation capacity in both developing and developed countries. AgMIP is designed to provide an integrated, transdisciplinary framework to assess climate impacts on the agricultural sector and will build capacity for continuing agricultural assessment and management in developing countries under changing climate conditions. Given the congruence of its aims with those of CCAFS, ways are being explored to build synergies between the two efforts. The first step was to involve developing country partners in the AgMIP start-up meeting in late 2010. CCAFS has continued to sponsor participants from its target regions in subsequent AgMIP meetings. item.title: Science meeting on systems analysis tools
item.description: Several CRPs are centrally involved in studying complex agro-ecosystems in which there may be both synergies and trade-offs involved in attaining the development outcomes of increased household incomes, increased food security, and sustainable enhancements to ecological services. While the specific research questions and challenges may vary between CRPs and regions, the approaches and tools needed to study such complex systems are often similar. Understanding system dynamics, identifying tipping points, and understanding trade-offs across temporal and spatial scales and actors requires knowledge to be integrated across several domains, including the biophysical and the socio-economic. A workshop will be organised with some 15-20 scientists engaged in research in relevant CRPs. Several case studies will be developed prior to the workshop, to illustrate the challenges that need to be addressed. Participants will include a mix of CRPS scientists and a few external speakers that can bring novel and relevant system approaches from diverse backgrounds to the meeting.

item.title: Initiation of a case study at one CCAFS site on developing approaches to support smallholder decision making, to link with both the met service work and the household modelling work
item.description: Farmers in Sub-Sahara Africa, operating in risky and unpredictable environments, have to make decisions with very limited information available to them. Research on farmers perceptions of climate change and variability indicate that in many communities there are perceptions, particularly regarding amounts and timing of rainfall, that are i) not generally reflected in analysed climatic data and ii) contradictory. Consequently farmers may be making decisions and implementing both short term management practices and longer term strategies that are inappropriate. Analysed historical data (from daily records made over several decades) is increasingly being made available in several countries (through work undertaken by UoR with partner institutions). At the same time a range of participatory approaches (including participatory farm management methods [Dorward et al 2003]) exist that could be adapted and used to communicate with farmers about analysed climate information in ways that enable farmers to make more informed (and therefore improved) short and longer term livelihood, farm and crop decisions. Key to this is understanding what information farmers want and need, being able to provide it in ways that are easy to understand and at the same time enable facilitate meaningful consideration of implications. Forecasts (long, medium and short) can provide further information of value to planning and decision making. Attempts to introduce these to farmers have had mixed success. With the improved understanding from the above there is scope to add some of these to the information that farmers receive in a more integrated and useful way. Preliminary fieldwork in Zimbabwe (June/July 2012) confirmed the need for and potential of research on this topic. Smallholders, working with extension staff successfully used a range of approaches in the initial steps 1-4 (steps summarised later in this document). Work is required to test the full approach at a range of locations with different characteristics (climate, agriculture, socioeconomic), draw lessons and facilitate wider implementation and scaling up. Capacity building amongst service providers, particularly extension services and NGOs that work directly with smallholders forms a necessary and important part of the project.

item.title: Development of global agroforestry suitability maps in a changed climate
item.description: South Asia has about half of the Worlds poor, and the poverty wide spread throughout the region. The region is characterized by low resource base, few income generating opportunities, a web of socio-political conflicts and low extent of education. These factors and inappropriate policies lead to food and income insecurity and make the community vulnerable to climate change effects. The region recognizes agroforestry as an important avenue for improving livelihoods, harnessing environmental services and buffering against climate change, and each country has estimated the potential area for agroforestry. For example, India estimated 28 m ha; 18 m ha in the rainfed and 10 m ha in irrigated lands. However, which agroforestry system would be suitable in which agro-climatic condition is not known, and this has limited the practice of agroforestry in most of them. Therefore, it requires the assessment of agroforestry trajectories, and development of appropriate methodologies to do so.

item.title: Response of grassland growth to climate change on the Tibetan Plateau (TP)
item.description: Vegetation growth, which was regulated by climate change to some extent, has an essential function in regulating carbon and energy exchange in terrestrial ecosystems. Considerable evidence shows that continuous warming occurred in the late 20th century and 2000 to 2009 has been the warmest years. Several studies have shown that the increase of vegetation growth during the 1980s -1990s may be stalled or even reversed in some region of Eurasia during last decade. Various reasons have been found, for instance drought, spring cooling etc. Previous studies demonstrated that spring phenology on Tibetan Plateau (TP) has advanced before mid-1990s and retreated afterwards, which primarily causes the shortening of the length of growing season. This will eventually lead to variation in vegetation growth. No detailed research has been done in terms of vegetation growth response to climate change under the context of complex climate change and shortened growing season on TP.

item.description: The CCAFS multi-site agricultural trial initiative, started in 2010, builds on the wealth of technology evaluations available for modeling climate change adaptation by standardizing and consolidating data that will be used by the scientific community to build adaptation road maps. The effort has now completed initial development of databases, file repositories, web interfaces, communication protocols and processes for further development of a powerful information resource for the agricultural research community. Project partnerships have been developed to motivate the growth and development of the information resource. Significant advances made with GCP, the Tropical Legumes project, UC-Riverside, Monsanto, AgMips and the CGIAR centers. Efforts at fund raising have been mixed, with good leveraging of co-finance (GCP, Tropical Legumes, etc), but lacking a major grant for future sustainability. In 2012 the Agtrials project should become consolidated and mature leaving a system that is fully ready to be utilized by the international crop improvement community.

item.title: Development of a method to study farmerand apos;s social, cultural and gender specific barriers for enabling behavioral change and improve adaptive capacity, based on farmers exchanges between climatic analogues locations (Farms of the Future Africa)
item.description: The and apos;Farms of the Futureand apos; project will use the CCAFS climate analogue tool to connect farmers to their possible climate futures via farm visits. Through this novel anthropological approach of farmer-to-farmer exchanges between spatial analogues, CCAFS aims to establish a sound methodology allowing identification of social, cultural and gender specific barriers for enabling behavioral change, therefore, an increased adaptive capacity. The project will particularly improve understanding of social and cultural perceptions of future climates, local practices and available tools for enabling change, as well as cultural, economic, or institutional obstacles to such adaptive change (e.g., no existing market for cultivation of an otherwise promising substitution crop). The adopted approach will allow the participatory diagnosis of capacities and needs, thus aiding in the design of community-appropriate adaptation strategies. Once refined, the methodology will be global enough to be applicable anywhere. It will provide policy makers with key socio-cultural information to tailor local adaptation strategies and habilitate scientists to validate computational models with analogue proxies and to ground mathematical projections with qualitative, real world assessments. Furthermore, it will help refine the analogue tool itself to include non-biophysical variables.

item.title: Farms of the future approach: Understanding social and cultural barriers to climate change adaption through farmer exchanges
item.description: Scientific evidence gathered in the last couple of decades suggests that climate conditions are changing rapidly and that this trend will likely continue and even accelerate. These anticipated changes in climate baseline, variability and extremes will have far-reaching consequences on agricultural production, posing additional challenges to meeting food security for a growing world population. As climate migrates between regions, it will disproportionally affect resource-poor and marginalized farmers who have lower adaptive capacities but may depend entirely on agriculture for their livelihoods. Therefore, male and female farmers alike need to enhance their adaptive capacities. Achieving adapted farming systems for changing climate conditions in space and time will require the development of new technologies and testing across a range of pilot sites, as well as modeling activities to outscale the potential of individual adaptation options across a widerange of geographies. The CCAFS Farms of the Future project will use the climate analogue tool to connect farmers to their possible climate futures via farm visits. This project will address the following working hypothesis: by identifying and connecting analogue sites, research can: 1) enable farmers to better envision how their site-specific agricultural future might look, and 2) permit targeted on-the-ground testing of cropping systems/technologies climate resilience. In sum, we are hoping to learn the potential of the climate analogues tool/methodology to improve farmers adaptive capacities and preparedness for eventual transformational adaptation.

item.title: Varietal diversification to manage climate risk in East Africa
item.description: Having diverse crops and varieties potentially forms a natural insurance against climate change risk. It could also provide the basis for adaptive management under progressive climate change. Designed diversification strategies can help farmers to add varieties and crops to their mixture to make their varietal portfolio less vulnerable to climate risk. The project will produce insights on the potential of varietal diversification strategies in CCAFS benchmark sites, allowing for comparisons between sites (what works where and why) and with other intervention strategies. The project will assess levels of diversity of different major crops in benchmark sites in East Africa, assess the current vulnerability of varieties and varietal portfolios, and identify varietal diversification needs and opportunities. Based on this information, varietal diversification strategies will be designed and tested in the field, introducing existing landrace and improved materials to farmers. Applying the approach in the CCAFS benchmark sites would make it possible to compare the impact determine which advantages and disadvantages it has relative to alternative technologies and interventions.

The first phase of this work in 2012 with CCAFS support inwill be Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, India, South Asia. The second phase (starting in 2013) will be in Rajasthan with CRP1.1 support. and will be conducted in CRP1.1 research sites. We will assess vulnerability and other household characteristics (gender, livelihoods, indigenous knowledge) and farm typologies that are likely to influence household capacity to adapt to climate variability and change. We will work with policy-makers and other institutions that enable livelihood and agricultural technology options, including PPP for mechanization and insurance. We will converge programmes in order to work across scales. These activities will be linked to other CCAFS and CRP1.1projects in South Asia and will use or be compatible with CCAFS baseline instruments.

item.title: Participatory Evaluation and Promotion of integrated sorghum - legume technologies for improved food security and income in Wote district of Eastern Kenya
item.description: Increasingly-recognized environmental threats such as climate change, land degradation and biodiversity loss have added new dimensions to the on-going challenges such as drought, increasing population pressure, and rising costs of food and inputs in the dry tropics. Most of the inhabitants of the dryland areas struggle to wrest a meagre living from agriculture and tragically, they are missing out on large potential productivity gains that are biologically possible given the soils, crops and climates of these areas, as proven by decades of research across a wide range of dryland locations (World Bank, 2008). Sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L.) as a C4, hot-season cereal crop, is adapted to a wide range of environmental and soil fertility conditions and has been termed it as one of the Climate Change Ready Crops (ASARECA, 2010). Small scale farmers often intercrop sorghum with legumes such as cowpea, greengram, and lablab bean to provide the protein that supplement the carbohydrates and starch from sorghum. This project will bring to the mainstream, the sorghum system and some legume crops with inherent resilience to drought and hence enhance the food basket for households in the dry areas. The goal is to improve the livelihoods of the poor rural smallholder farming households in arid and semi-arid areas of Eastern Kenya. The main objective of the project is to support the evaluation, dissemination and uptake of new sorghum and legume technologies and also explore opportunities to create farmer market linkages. The project will focus on Wote district - one of the CCAFS sites in Eastern Kenya. The project will be implemented in collaboration with KARI Katumani. and the extension staff in 5 selected villages in Wote district.

item.title: Increasing Womenand apos;s Resilience to Confront Climate Change
item.description: There is some evidence to suggest that unequal access to and control over assets make women particularly vulnerable to the negative impacts of climate change both in terms of their sensitivity to climate shocks and their adaptive capacity. Men and women are also likely to have very different perceptions of climate change and climate risk, and very different approaches to adaptation. But there is very little data or analysis of gender differences in climate change impacts or ability to engage in climate-smart agriculture. Improved information on these issues is needed to design gender-sensitive and pro-poor climate change research approaches that will benefit women and men.

The research will be done in conjunction with work on gender sentinel sites, and contribute to strategies to increase resilience for women as well as men.

item.title: Assessing the impact of appropriate risk management financial packages on households asset portfolios in Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Uruguay
item.description:
Index insurance is an innovative financial product that helps rural households manage large covariate shocks to agricultural income. Current research is increasingly showing that an effective risk management strategy in the face of climate change will require a combination of indexed insurance, savings and credit and that the correct combination of these three financial products will likely depend on the nature of climatic shocks and rural financial markets
If rural communities have access to such risk management tools they can increase the degree to which they are able to withstand climate risks. The ultimate effect of insurance on the resilience of rural households is thus an empirical question that is likely to vary depending on the situation being considered. However one key difficulty to collect empirical data is that index insurance is a new product, that requires training and proper information and that is subject to basis risk. Therefore in order to collect relevant information and study the impact of actual purchase of index insurance these issues need to be address.

item.ccafs:objective: This activity will address the issue of potential low index insurance take-up and on the implications for relevant data collection to analyze its impact on consumption and production decisions. Ongoing RCT studies require as much support as possible to induce higher take-up rates among potential customers that will allow to observe actual decisions once insurance purchase decision has been made. This activity will provide support to data collection processes in ongoing RCT studies through different options, among them: qualitative data collection, better training to customers, reduction of basis risk through additional low cost weather stations, demand incentives like discounts or rebates, and additional sample size.

item.title: Building climate smart farming systems in Rakai (Uganda)
item.description: ILRI and IITA are currently jointly organizing the CCAFS farming systems survey in Rakai where coffee/banana systems are dominant. This project will use participatory approaches with farmers, local extension and governance actors, and NGOs to discuss the constraints and opportunities of the coffee/banana system. The focus will be on climate change and adaptation and mitigation strategies that improve farmers livelihoods and increase system resilience. Different qualitative approaches will be used to organize knowledge exchange between research and farmer communities and support services. A strongly quantitative approach will be linked to this work to map plot, household, and community level resource flows. This will be used to analyse trade-offs at farm and community / landscape level. Taking into consideration farmers preferences and resource limitations, a series of promising scenarios will be developed and discussed.

item.title: Gender inequality: A barrier to climate adaptation behavior?
item.description: The study will examine how gender inequality influences household adaptation decisions in Bangladesh, through shaping womenand apos;s and menand apos;s perceptions of risk and their capacities to adapt. The adaptation decision in question is whether or not to invest in cage culture of fish, a new activity introduced to offer an opportunity to diversify livelihood systems. However, investing in the activity itself brings risks that may bar some farm households from investing and gaining the expected benefits. The research will explore how gender norms, attitudes and practices influence the way women and men assess the cage culture opportunity in terms of ots risks and their capacities to adapt, and whether and how these gendered assesments create barriers to households being able or willing to take up and sustain the activity.

item.title: Best bets for climate-smart agriculture: The scientific basis
item.description: Everywhere you turn it seems someone is talking about climate-smart agriculture (CSA). Development practitioners and the popular press are drunk on the idea, policy makers take a more sobering perspective, and scientists seem puzzled, skeptical, and concerned. Despite the mixed emotions, CSA has quickly been integrated into the global development agenda. There is an urgent need to examine CSA objectivity to understand what is really known about purported CSA practices and technologies, the synergies and tradeoffs among its 3-pillars, and socio-ecological niches where CSA is or is not appropriate to calibrate expectations and inform discourse. This project aims to assess the scientific basis for CSA. That is, separate what is well-established from what is more uncertain about proposed CSA practices. Specific focus will be on cataloging CSA being examined under the CGIAR but scope will be expanded as time and resources permit.

item.title: Managing climate related risks to improve livelihood resilience and adaptive capacity in agricultural ecosystems in Southern Mozambique
item.description: Within the Government of Mozambique there is a strong interest in, and a growing commitment to climate change issues. At the national level, the government is leading efforts to raise the topic of climate change on the development agenda. Mozambique is particularly vulnerable to climate change due to its geographic location at the confluence of many international rivers flowing into the Indian Ocean; its land area that is below sea level; high vulnerability to cyclones and storms; high temperatures; aridity; infertile soils; lack of communications infrastructure; a high level of illiteracy; high population growth rate; absolute poverty and a high dependence on natural resources that require predictable rain. In the next twenty years Mozambique is predicted to lose 25 per cent of its agricultural productive capacity. These changes will negatively affect crop yields resulting in price increases for basic staples, which can have a serious effect on health and increasing child malnutrition. Systems need to be put into place to manage the risks from such weather and climate variability. The ability to smooth gains and losses due to climate variability requires improved climate information and an institutional framework in which the public and private sector can act quickly and efficiently when provided reliable information.

item.title: A methodological development of an online tool for the identification of Target Population Environments: improving the predictions of agricultural production using crop models
item.description: The expected increases in temperature and shifts in precipitation regimes are predicted to cause significant changes in crop productivity across the globe, through direct abiotic influence or through associated changes in pest and disease pressure. While significant adaptive capacity exists within agricultural and socio-economic systems, models suggest that the germplasm that currently underpins production is likely to be out-reached in some places by change. Hence, crop improvement through conventional breeding or through biotechnological innovations is hailed as a crucial strategy to ensure long-term maintenance or gain in agricultural productivity. Given the long lead-time between commencement of a breeding program and the release and large-scale adoption of new cultivars in farmers fields, it is critical that breeding programs are initiated today to address future problems. It is therefore key that priorities are developed for crop improvement programs based on sound ex-ante analysis of future benefits, and that coherent strategies across multiple countries and between institutions are adopted and implemented. International and national donor and government policies should be coordinated in enabling the conception and implementation of these strategies.

item.title: Adaptation strategies for crops to climate change (CIRAD)
item.description: This project serves to develop adaptation strategies for crops to climate change, based on crop improvement through breeding. A crop modeling approach using present and future climate scenarios is to be implemented. Once appropriate crop models have been improved and calibrated/validated, they will be used to (1) measure the impact of climate change scenarios on existing crop varieties, and (2) determine trait combinations (ideotype concepts) that would improve adaptation and performance. item.title: Farm level modeling for ex-ante evaluation of index-based insurance
item.ccafs:deliverableTitle: Report and paper to be submitted as DP and/or journal on its application to index insurance
Farm level structural model
item.ccafs:objective: This research will use the latest techniques in structural modeling and randomized control trials (RCTs) to calibrate a behavioral model that allows us to make predictions about the likely impact of index insurance and other financial instruments on a rural communities resilience to climate related risk, more specifically droughts. Specifically the structural model will captures household behavior and incorporates: (i) a households decision to purchase insurance; (ii) household investments in risky agricultural technologies, and (iii) household consumption decisions. This model will allow us to generate predictions on: a) optimal design of index insurance products, b) the optimal combination of financial products required to manage climate risk and c) the likely impact of these products on agricultural investments and ultimately household welfare.

item.title: Developing community-based climate smart agriculture through participatory action research in five benchmark sites in West Africa
item.description: One of CGIAR Research Program on Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (CCAFS) over-arching objectives is to assess and test pro-poor adaptation and mitigation practices, technologies and policies for food systems, adaptive capacity and rural livelihoods. This task will be carried out through an adaptive placed-based research structured around three Themes (Adaptation to progressive climate change, Adaptation through risk management and Pro-poor mitigation) aiming to decrease the vulnerability of rural communities and enable them to prosper under a variable and changing climate. A fourth Theme Integration for Decision Making will ensure effective engagement with rural communities and institutional and policy stakeholders, grounds it in the policy context, and provide, through a demand-driven process, downscaled analyses and tools for future climates. The question is how to balance crop production while sustaining the diverse ecosystem services provided by agricultural landscapes in response to future climate change? As an example, one of the key mechanisms is the use of sound agroforestry systems by which diverse perennial plant communities can confer greater resilience and stability of key ecosystem functions relative to annual or simplified cropping systems, thereby enhancing overall adaptive capacity to environmental change. It is based on comparative advantage that CCAFS-WA has identifier ICRAF to lead the facilitation process of the participatory action research about climate smart agriculture. The overall methodological approach will capitalize on-going actions and findings of existing projects, act to encourage partners to add missing components to the existing and on-going projects and initiate new activities when deemed appropriate. More specifically, this PAR work will use the climate smart village model approach (see figure below) to implement the various projects and activities that will be defined through participatory identification of gaps and research priorities in each country/site. This will be mainly led by the multi-disciplinary teams that will be formed in each country to conduct the work. The work should where possible, build on existing projects and be located at CCAFS benchmark sites. Priority countries sites are Cinzana (Sgou region, Mali), Lawra (Lawra-Jirapa region, Ghana), Tougou (Yatenga region, Burkina Faso), Fakara (Kollo region, Niger) and Kaffrine (Kaffrine region, Senegal). Other projects/initiatives in other countries in the sub-region could be considered if strongly relevant. In view of the specificity of certain components of the work, ICRAF will have to liaise with identified partners (e.g. components on climate services and weather insurance will be separately covered through AGRHYMET) to incorporate their outputs in the climate smart village work. A range of options will be tested across a range of soil, climatic and socio-economic conditions, and their adoption, adaptation and performance will be assessed. They should be integrative of the climate smart village components described below and will be identified by the country multi-disciplinary teams using a participatory approach during the first workshop.

item.ccafs:objective: To test and validate, in partnership with rural communities and other stakeholders, a scalable climate-smart model for agricultural development that integrates a range of innovative agricultural risk management strategies.
